name: Earth's Hidden Sovereign
author: 0_Dark Crow
description:
When Gu Jun was twelve, he inscribed an ancient epitaph on a forgotten gravestone atop Temple Hill — in a language no one on Earth should know.

Now eighteen, Gu Jun is preparing to begin his university life in Tianhai. To everyone around him, he’s just a quiet, unremarkable student. But beneath that façade lies a cosmic legacy — the inheritance of Emperor Qin, the last sovereign of our Universe, the Wild Universe.

Earth, long sealed from the higher realms, is no longer safe. Ancient enemies stir beyond the veil of stars. Forbidden truths bleed into the world of mortals. The coming war won't just be fought with armies — it will be waged in silence, in shadows, and in secret.

To protect Earth and the Universe, Gu Jun must build what the world must never know: a hidden empire. Trained in cultivation. Forged in secrecy. Bound by destiny.

And as the final battle looms, warriors must rise from the dark — or all of creation may fall.

Author's Note:
I’ve been a long-time fan of legendary writers like Er Gen, I Eat Tomatoes, and Mao Ni; their stories have inspired me for over a decade. In my own writing, I aim to follow in their footsteps.

Don’t expect the protagonist to slaughter rivers of enemies in the first chapter. This isn’t a story built on cheap thrills. Instead, I focus on building a solid foundation, establishing the world, characters, and deeper plots. Once that’s in place, expect action, intrigue, betrayal, and tragedy to unfold.

# If you enjoy:

*Medium-Paced Stories with Long-Term Scheming,

*A Bigger Picture,

*Cultivation,

*Way of the Emperor (Emperor is always right),

*Some litRPG Elements,

*Family, Sect, Secret, Darkness, Tragedy, Betrayal

*Dao, Dao Heart, and Heavenly Dao

*Light Romance (Harem? may be)

I invite you to follow this journey.

*I will release three chapters per week.

Happy reading, and thank you for your support!

reviews.title: Very good.
reviews.content:
Very good.
REVIEWED AT: 15. The Sister-In-Law Incident
BY Fine young man
7/21/2025, 5:07 AM

This is, unironically, very readable. You got flow, the scene pacing is rarely boring, and the power/political stuff is introduced in a way that doesn’t feel like a dry wiki dump. You’re playing heavily in the “Webnovel Cultivation/Modern Reincarnation” genre (e.g. Urban Cultivation, Emperor’s Domination, etc.), but you do it with more self-awareness and some actual character focus.

Visuals: Strong, cinematic intro. “Edge of the solar system” is classic Xianxia-but-with-space, and the “Emperor Qin” setup is hard genre bait, but you sell it well.

Language: “His tattered imperial robes fluttered silently, despite the absence of wind.” = clean line.

Downside: Not original—this is classic cultivation trope (ancient emperor, last hope, universe in peril). But you do it better than most, and the existential fatigue is there.

Nitpick: “He was Emperor Qin—the last sovereign of the human race from this universe, known as the Wild Universe.”

It’s a little dry, but whatever, it does its job.

You skip the purple prose most CNs drown in.

The “savior emerges from the Solar System” is a nice cosmic touch.

Stakes are instantly clear.

Seen this trope before. Not gonna lie. Feels like a blend of “I Shall Seal the Heavens” with “History’s Strongest Senior Brother.”

Opening with the Bike Scene: Bro, this is actually great. Simple, slice-of-life, sets up MC as a real human, not a “chosen one” from page one.

Atmosphere: The ruined temple, silent hill, strange energy—gives off low-key melancholy and isolation.

Parental Stuff: You handle broken families better than 90% of webnovels. Not melodramatic, but not cold.

Line to Highlight: “I don’t know if I should love you… or hate you. You placed a mountain on my back before I even had the strength to stand straight. Do you know what that’s like?”

This is fire. Shows resentment without being a whiner.

Every flashback feels like it belongs, not just a forced info-dump.

“Supreme Immortal Script”—nice lore drip, not over-explained.

Dialogue is believable, not cringy.

Sometimes the world-building names (“Wild Universe”, “Death Race”, “Solar Seal”) sound like placeholders.

Watch out for repetition: “His thoughts drifted to the past, toward the strange journey that had been his eighteen years of life.” You use this a lot.

Empire Power Structure: Low-key, your description of shadow empires and cultivation networks is actually engaging. Reads like a strategy board, not a list.

Heaven-Encompassing Array—not just a generic “barrier,” but some thought put into geopolitics, ley lines, etc.

The Xiao Family beef: This is how you do slow-burn antagonists, not just mustache-twirling idiots.

Twin Shadows and “Elders” = classic, but you add some flavor.

“It didn't conquer—it curated.” Good shit. Empire by influence, not force, is rare in these stories.

Imperial Cigarette—Bro, this is original and memeable. A power-up ritual that’s a literal smoke break? Peak.

The “Emperor’s presence” switch is getting a little old. He’s lowkey always “radiating pressure” every other chapter. Dial it back or make the shifts more subtle, or it feels like pressing a video game buff key.

Dialogue for subordinates (Longwei, elders) is a little copy-paste. You could give them more personality.

Lin Mo’s flashback: Brutal, visceral, and dark—nice. But you jump into another tragic backstory pretty fast. Maybe pace the trauma dumps a bit more?

“Noise brings death.” Excellent line.

Lin Mo’s training and trauma reads as real, not just “edgy for edge’s sake.”

“Every covert operation, every silent mission, every whisper in the dark answers to him.”

That’s how you establish a true shadow master.

The “three personal guards” concept is actually explained well—not just “because I’m the MC.”

Starting to feel like every single important person has some secret trauma or shadow organization. Give someone a normal family just for spice, even if they get murdered later lmao.

Train Scene: Chef’s kiss. Plays with tropes (arrogant young master, beauty duo, “pay to switch seats”), then subverts with Rong Xi telling him to stay instead of rolling over. The Wang Wei drama is classic but fun.

Campus hierarchy & flower rankings: You get the social dynamic right, even if it’s a trope (flower rankings, family clans, underworld, etc.)

MC’s “average looks”: It’s a little played out (“I look mid but I got swag”), but at least you don’t oversell it.

Dialogue is snappy and way less cringey than 99% of similar novels.

You’re very self-aware: “Bro, you really don’t value your life, do you?” re: Bai Yue’s family.

MC keeps going “I don’t care, not yet.” Feels like you’re stalling on letting him engage with the world for real. Let him make a move.

The side characters (Xiao Wei, Zhou Hao, etc.)—great setup, but they risk feeling like carbon copies unless you let them act against the MC once in a while.

Humor is solid: The “brother-in-law” running gag is good, and Gu Jun’s trolling of Bai Xue is actually funny.

Romance: You’re teasing harem territory without jumping in headfirst, which is good. No simping, MC doesn’t get flustered.

Too Many Introductions: The first 10 chapters throw a lot of new characters, family names, and power levels at the reader. Pace these out more, or some will become forgettable.

Family Names: Bai, Rong, Xiao, Wang, Hong, Yang, Su—classic, but start associating them with actual values or personalities fast, or it’ll blur into “who’s who” soup.

Power System: Vitality Sensation, Bright Energy, Dark Strength, HuaJin, Innate, Divine—It’s standard, but you explain it well. Don’t bog down in numbers or stats, just use show-don’t-tell where possible.

MC Power Progression: If you slow-roll his cultivation too long, you risk “blue-balling” your readers. You teased “overpowered but hiding,” so let him pop off at least once in the first 20 chapters or they’ll get bored.

Imperial Cigarette. No seriously, that’s iconic.

MC is a manipulator, not a brick wall. He’s got actual EQ and social engineering skills.

Villains feel real: Wang Wei isn’t just a random clown, he’s a believable spoiled kid.

Political intrigue > endless fighting. Love that you build threats through social structures, not just punching bags.

Banter: Dialogue is the highlight.

You’re well above average for webnovel/cultivation stuff.
You’re also not afraid to let MC be a little unlikable, which is rare and good. Your humor lands, your power structure is clear (if a bit familiar), and the social intrigue is spicy.

Give your major side characters a memorable quirk or two to separate them. (E.g., Xiao Wei is not just “the peacock,” maybe he’s a germaphobe, or he’s obsessed with classical music, etc.)

Don’t let Gu Jun “monologue in his head” every single chapter. Use his actions and dialogue to show his growth/conflict.

Hit us with a fight or real confrontation soon—can be social, can be violent, but we need payoff.

This is readable, memeable, and actually has some emotional punch. You’ve got the sauce. Just watch the infodumps and introductions, and don’t drag out the “hidden emperor” bit too long.

The story has been a nice slow burn so far. the early pacing is deliberate. But that’s the point. Every chapter lays another brick in the foundation of something bigger. The author takes time to flesh out the setting, hint at the wider universe, and give weight to every interaction. When things finally start to move, the payoff hits hard.

The prose leans poetic at times—sometimes a bit flowery—but it suits the tone. Gu Jun's internal narration reads like someone who's seen more than he lets on, which keeps you guessing about his real motives and capabilities.

Minor gripes? Dialogue can occasionally feel stiff, and the exposition might trip up readers expecting a more action-heavy opening. But if you’re here for smart world-building, cold charisma, and a protagonist who never shows his full hand—this is absolutely worth the read.

The author has constructed a world that has clear thought and planning behind it. What we’ve seen in the first twenty two chapters is only the tip of the iceberg when compared with what’s coming. There is a clear scale for the power that, while inherent in the xianxia genre, hints at a depth of planning on the authors part that goes beyond the early plot. 


This is definitely a slow burn story, and the characters are only just beginning to show their colors. There is a complicated political web that is slowly being unveiled for the reader, with the MC, even though he does not yet demonstrate prodigious strength, at the center. He is building a supporting cast of powerful characters, who each have a unique attitude that is fitting within the tropes of the genre. The only negative note with the characters is that some of the more complicated scenes with many characters got a little confusing, and at times I wasn’t sure the right character was referenced. 

There author’s style is consistent throughout the story, and helps serve as a driving force to keep the reader moving. While the chapters are on the shorter side, their endings come across as planned to maximize continued reading. 


The grammar is the weakest point of this story. It pulled me out at times because it does change tenses frequently. I have a feeling that the grammatical issues I encountered likely stem from English not being the author’s first language, and translations not perfectly capturing their native tongue. With that in mind, I found the issues far less distracting and had no trouble getting through the work, because the story itself is worth it!

reviews.content:
A Beautifully Written Story
REVIEWED AT: 11. A Brother-in-Law, Uninvited
BY Gettsenova
7/2/2025, 2:25 AM

Earth’s Hidden sovereign is a wonderful example of the Xianxia genre. The author does a fantastic job providing extensive storytelling and an interesting perspective through wonderful writing.

The narrative wastes no time immersing the reader into its core conflict and high stakes. You know right off the bat what kind of journey you’re in for, with the overarching goal appearing from the get-go. The beginning is focused on world-building and paints a clear picture of the main characters surrounding and goals.

Unlike many stories, where the main character starts out as the clear underdog, the MC in this story has a unique experience and mindset. They aren’t new to a seat of power, already experienced and used to carrying the weight of the world on their shoulders. They’ve developed skills and connections that come with that experience, not relying on physical strength himself (at least so far).

The author has a very clear and unique writing style that lends itself well to this story and genre. Their prose is often flowery and dramatic, giving it an almost poetic feel that helps heighten the scale and sense of importance. But to prevent being overbearing, the author does a good job of dialing it back when necessary to not overwhelm the reader, using it to elevate the important aspects of his story. This is exceptionally helpful as the epic scale of the story is clear from the beginning, with talk of fate and protecting the universe weaved in. Appropriately, much of the cast is also larger than life, with pieces of sacred beasts and emperors involved, making this story truly feel extraordinary.

The only complaint I have about this story is minor. The prologue needs a little work at the time of writing this.  It moves in and out of present and past tense, and there’s a strange formatting issue that isn’t present in the other chapters. This is much more obvious on mobile devices, simply appearing to be a different font size on computer.  

Overall, Earth’s Hidden Sovereign does an incredible job at immersing the reader in a well-crafted cultivation story. The writing is beautiful and with a unique setting for the main character, it provides a refreshing change in the standard perspective that I strongly recommend.

chapters.content:
At the very edge of the solar system…

If anyone had been watching through a deep-space satellite, they would have been left speechless.

A lone figure stood suspended in the cosmic void, where there should have been nothing but the silent drift of asteroids and the cold shimmer of distant stars. Yet there he was, a man, ancient, battered, and emanating a presence that defied reason.

His face was resolute, carved by the trials of time and war, yet hollowed by exhaustion. His tattered imperial robes fluttered silently, despite the absence of wind.

This was no ordinary man.

He was Emperor Qin, the last sovereign of the human race from this universe, known as the Wild Universe.

His body was nearly drained of spiritual essence. To seal the Wild Universe and halt the invasion of the dreaded Death Race, Emperor Qin had sacrificed nearly all of his cultivation. His life force flickered like a dying star. And yet, through sheer will, he had reached the outer boundary of this forgotten cradle of humanity, the Solar System.

Before him, like a blue jewel resting in the dark, floated Earth.

His eyes, dim yet unyielding, stared at the planet with a mix of reverence and urgency.

“So… this is the Mother. This is the ancestral land,” he whispered hoarsely. “The origin of life in the Wild Universe…”

The words of the ancient sages echoed in his mind:

“As long as the Solar System endures, the human race shall never perish.”

For billions of years, it had been forbidden for outsiders to enter the Solar System. This law was meant to preserve peace and purity. But alas, Emperor Qin had no other choice now. He had to take this chance.

It was said that when the Wild Universe faced a true life-and-death crisis, the savior would always emerge from the Solar System. He could see it now: originally, there had been only two planets here, but the ancestors had divided them into eight to complete the Sacred Array, the formation that protected the system.

It wasn’t a problem for him. He was the Emperor, and he held the key to entering the Solar System.

Emperor Qin could feel his life slipping through his fingers like grains of sand lost to the cosmic wind. His time was short. His energy was fading. But his mission was not yet complete.

There was still one thing left to do.

With the last remnants of his strength, he turned toward Earth, his aura flickering weakly.

“I must find the heir… someone worthy of the throne. Someone who can inherit the legacy… and protect our universe.”

And with that thought, he vanished into a streak of radiant light, descending silently toward the distant blue planet—

—where the final chapter of an ancient legacy was about to begin.

Greatness begins with a single step into the unknown.

Will you take that step by my side?

-Dark Crow

chapters.name: 1. The Silent Oath
chapters.content:
Gu Jun pedaled steadily through the quiet countryside, the early morning sun casting long, golden streaks across the narrow road. The cool wind brushed against his face, carrying the scent of dew-drenched grass and distant blooming jasmine. The wheels of his old bicycle hummed along the pavement, rhythmic and peaceful, until a sudden shadow darted into his path.

An old lady stepped out from the roadside brush.

Startled, Gu Jun gripped the brakes.
The tires screeched, skidding just inches from her.

She didn’t flinch.

Instead, the old woman looked at him with oddly familiar eyes and let out a dry chuckle. “Hey, brat. Where are you off to in such a rush?”

Gu Jun blinked, tension easing as he recognized her. She was one of the village elders; quiet, strange, and always watching. He gave a faint smile. “Temple Hill.”

The woman nodded slowly, a distant gleam in her eye. “Then go. Don’t keep the dead waiting.”

Gu Jun offered a polite bow. “Goodbye, old granny.”

She watched silently as he rode off, her figure shrinking in the distance.

After a short ride, Gu Jun reached the base of Temple Hill. He dismounted and leaned his bicycle against the roots of an ancient tree. Slinging his backpack over one shoulder, he began the steep climb. Birds chirped in the distance, but the hill itself was eerily silent.

At the summit stood the ruined temple, worn by time, half-swallowed by nature. Vines coiled around crumbling stone columns, and moss carpeted the fractured floor. Despite its decay, the temple radiated a strange gravity, as if the very air around it remembered glory long since lost.

Behind the temple, hidden among overgrowth and thorny shrubs, lay a solitary grave.

Gu Jun pushed aside the brambles and stepped into the forgotten clearing. At the grave’s head stood a simple stone tablet, cracked and faded by rain and years. Etched into its face were symbols that no human scholar could read, yet to Gu Jun, they were as clear as his own name.

The characters shimmered faintly with residual energy: the Supreme Immortal Script; a language so ancient and sacred that even emperors of the Immortal World treated it with reverence.

He stared at the words, and as he had so many times before, they echoed through his mind like a voice carried by time:

“Here lies a warrior. A hero of the world.
Protector of the human race.
Supreme Emperor of the Wild Universe.”

Six years ago, Gu Jun had carved those words himself, with his own finger, pressed into the stone like a chisel forged from spirit and grief.

Back then, he had been just twelve.

Now he was eighteen, on the cusp of adulthood, the weight of worlds resting on his shoulders.

His expression darkened as he looked at the grave. Silence hung in the air.

“Old man…” he murmured, his voice cracking. “I’m leaving for Tianhai today. University starts soon.”

He knelt and began clearing away the fallen leaves and dirt, brushing the grave clean with practiced care.

“It’s been six years since you vanished… two since Father passed. And Mom… Well, you already know. I’m alone now. You left me with nothing but questions. Nothing but duty.”

He stood again, eyes fixed on the stone.

“I don’t know if I should love you… or hate you. You placed a mountain on my back before I even had the strength to stand straight. Do you know what that’s like?”

He exhaled shakily, the wind catching the edges of his jacket.

“But I haven’t forgotten your mission. Not a day passes without it burning in my mind. They all think you ran from the war. That you abandoned the battlefield… abandoned them. Even your daughter probably believes you’re a coward.”

Gu Jun clenched his fists, trembling with the effort to hold something inside.

“But I know. You didn’t flee. You sacrificed everything to seal the Wild Universe, to keep the Death Race elites out. You bought time… and I won’t waste it.”

A faint glow flickered in his pupils. Deep inside him, something ancient stirred—power, dormant but alive.

“One day, I will enter that battlefield. I’ll unlock the Solar Seal. I’ll reignite the Great Cultivation Era. I’ll unite and lead the army of warriors, and crush the enemy that haunts our universe.”

He took a step closer, placing his palm gently against the cold stone.

“And I’ll make sure the world knows who you really were. Not a deserter… but a protector. Not a traitor… but the blade that held the darkness at bay.”

He bowed low, forehead touching the earth.

“This… is my oath.”

And as the wind whispered through the trees, it almost sounded like the temple whispered back.

chapters.name: 2. Reflections on the Road
chapters.content:
Gu Jun pedaled quietly down the slope from Temple Hill, the morning breeze brushing his face as the countryside rolled past. The rhythmic click of his bicycle chain echoed softly in the silence. His thoughts drifted to the past, toward the strange journey that had been his eighteen years of life.

His father, Gu Long, was born in this very village. A brilliant student, he had earned top scores and a scholarship to Capital University, the most prestigious institution in the country. It was there, amid the towering buildings and endless ambition, that he met Zi Feng.

Zi Feng, Gu Jun’s mother, came from the elite Zi family, one of the ten major families in the country. Back then, they ranked in the top five. Now, they were among the top three. Her name carried weight, her presence turned heads, and her ambitions soared far beyond the clouds.

Gu Jun’s birth wasn’t the result of love. It was the aftermath of a drunken mistake, two young people swept up in a moment, never intending for it to last.

When Zi Feng discovered she was pregnant, the news stirred some waves within her family, even in the whole capital. But the storm never reached its peak; her grandfather, the family patriarch, adored her. She was the brightest talent among her generation, and he refused to let scandal dim her light.

So, she and Gu Long agreed to marry. Out of responsibility, not affection.

But their worlds were never meant to align. Gu Long longed for a peaceful life in the countryside. Zi Feng, on the other hand, was born for power, for politics, for legacy. When Gu Jun was just two years old, she left, without ceremony or tears, and returned to the capital to pursue her destiny.

She never returned, not once during his father’s lifetime.

Yet, Gu Jun never let bitterness take root. His father made sure of that.

“She didn’t leave because she stopped loving you,” he would often say. “She left to protect her future… and maybe yours.”

The last time Gu Jun saw his mother was two years ago, at his father’s funeral.

Gu Long had passed quietly, a natural death. He hadn’t been old, not really. Just one morning, he didn’t wake up. There were no signs, no illness, no warning. It was as if something in him had simply… let go.

Despite all that had happened, Gu Long never remarried. He raised Gu Jun on his own, year after year, with quiet devotion and unshakable patience. Sometimes, Gu Jun would catch his father staring out the window, lost in thought.

And now he often wondered:

Was he happy?

But Gu Long never complained. He smiled often. Worked hard. And filled their little house with warmth. That, perhaps, was answer enough.

Gu Jun’s thoughts shifted to another figure in his life: Master Qin Di.

The villagers said he had arrived on Temple Hill more than thirty years ago, twelve years before Gu Jun was born. At first, people were curious about the strange man who muttered to himself and stared for hours at the sky. But over time, they decided he had lost his mind. He was dismissed as a harmless lunatic. Forgotten.

But the truth was far more profound.

When his calculations revealed that the next successor to the throne would be born in this village, he sealed away his memories and power to conserve his strength and waited.

And twelve years later, Gu Jun was born.

According to the tradition of the village, Gu Jun was born in the house, not in the hospital. There were several military doctors present during his birth, but something went wrong. The infant didn’t cry. He didn’t breathe. Panic broke out in the house. His family prepared to rush him to the military hospital.

And then Qin Di appeared.

Silent and focused, he stepped forward, placed his hand over the newborn’s chest, and Gu Jun took his first breath.

It was the moment fate awakened.

As the years passed, Qin Di became a constant in Gu Jun’s life. A mentor, a playmate, and eventually a teacher, though Gu Jun didn’t realize it at first. Many of his childhood days were spent at Temple Hill, listening to his master’s strange riddles, climbing the old temple ruins, or simply gazing at the stars beside him.

And then came that day.

Gu Jun was twelve years old.

Strangers came to the village, men cloaked in black, silent and ruthless. They weren’t robbers. They had come for him.

By then, Zi Feng had risen to power. After her grandfather’s death, she had taken the helm of the Zi family. With status came enemies. And they saw Gu Jun as a weakness they could exploit.

He hadn’t seen his mother in ten years.

But he didn’t resent her.

His father always said she had left to protect him. That she had hidden him away in this quiet village for his own safety. And when the attack came, he learned it was true.

A secret guard, stationed in the shadows by his mother, emerged to protect him. But there were too many attackers. Too skilled. The guard was overwhelmed.

Then Qin Di appeared.

With a single wave of his hand, the invaders were turned to dust.

But the cost was great.

To awaken his sealed power, Qin Di had shattered the bindings on his soul. His body began to collapse. His time was running out.

For one day and one night, Qin Di sat with Gu Jun beneath the ancient trees of Temple Hill. He spoke of histories. He told him of the Death Race, the Wild Universe, and the Solar Seal. It sounded like a fairy tale, but Gu Jun knew it was real.

Before his final breath, Qin Di transferred his last reserves of qi into Gu Jun’s body, cleansing it, refining it, preparing it to inherit the path ahead.

Then he was gone.

Gu Jun buried him on Temple Hill, under the crumbling shadow of the temple. And with his bare hand, he carved an epitaph into the gravestone in a language the earth had long since forgotten.

A silent vow etched in stone.
A legacy passed in silence.
And the beginning of something far greater.

chapters.name: 3. Beneath the Quiet Sky, a Storm Gathers
chapters.content:
Gu Jun pedaled steadily down the narrow road that wound through the countryside, leaving Temple Hill behind. He wasn't in a rush, but he couldn't afford to waste time. He had to reach home, grab his things, and head for Tianhai.

The bike creaked beneath him as it rolled downhill, tires humming softly over sunlit patches of gravel and grass. On either side, fields stretched in silence, tall stalks swaying in the still air like quiet observers. A few birds called out from the trees, and leaves whispered above, but none of it touched him. His mind was elsewhere.

Six years. That's how long the mantle had rested on him. The Wild Universe. A legacy older than memory, heavy, silent, star-wide. It wasn't something you wore; it was something that settled on you, buried you, forced you to stand tall anyway.

He wasn't building an empire of flags and crowns. Not a throne of gold or steel. No, his was an empire of influence. Of silence. Of control that moved beneath the surface like a current no one saw until it swept them away.

Truth be told, he also wanted to control everything openly, but that wasn’t possible right now. Too much was at stake, and too many threats lay beyond his control.

His thoughts flicked to scale. To the size of the world he intended to shape.
Earth now held more than ten billion people. And from that sea, three great forces had risen:

Country X: his homeland, the furnace where his vision took shape. It was his foundation.

Country M: a machine disguised as a state, layers of logic, networks of code, humming with invisible power.

Country B: forged in blood and sharpened by war, it clenched half the globe in its grip.

He knew better than to take them all on at once. The board was too large.
So he started at home, Country X. That was where the first real test would be.

Half of his total strength and resources were now concentrated in Country X. He must control it and be able to manipulate it according to his will.

Among this half, twenty percent was concentrated in Nator, the nation’s capital, as it was the power center. If you wanted to control a country, you had to control its capital. Ten percent was concentrated in Tianhai, as it was the current operations center. The remaining twenty percent was spread across ten other provinces.

Already, his hidden empire flowed through the nation's veins; wealth, intelligence, energy, cultivation, channeled with quiet precision.

The other half spread through the rest of the world.

Tianhai was the hinge. A coastal province flanked by trade routes, shielded by mountains, laced with ley lines, the old texts still whispered about. This was where the next act would begin.

And Gu Jun knew the burden of it would fall entirely on him. No one else could bear it. No one else would even understand it.

He was preparing something ancient. Something vast. The Heaven-Encompassing Array.

It was not a simple formation; this would wrap the entire province in a net of qi, geometry, spirit, and sacrifice. And once it was activated...

The skies would murmur his name. The rivers would echo it. Even the breath of the living would bend, ever so slightly, toward his will.

No secrets. No escape.

Only one problem remained. One piece refused to fit:

The Xiao family.

They ran Tianhai like it belonged to them. Money, muscle, backroom power, they had fingers in everything. From law enforcement to merchant guilds, from old temples to the latest telecom networks. And the irony? The Gu Empire had put them there.

Eighteen years ago, when Gu Jun was born, this plan was started. Back then, the Xiao were a middling clan, ambitious but limited in power. The Empire gave them scrolls. Gave them tools. Watched them climb.

First came loyalty. Then pride. Then arrogance.

Now they stood tall.

Too tall. They'd forgotten who fed them.

They thought they could push back against the very hand that carved their path.

A mistake.

The Gu Empire had always worked in the shadows. It didn't conquer, it curated. Quiet influence across countless domains. It tested, watched, and waited. And when people failed those tests, the consequences were already in place.

And The Xiao? They thought their independence was a sign of strength. That rising on their own meant they'd outgrown their lord.

Fools.

Sure, they had strength. Their old patriarch was no slouch, mid-Innate, and had a solid foundation. They had control over the underworld and the government. They'd clawed their way into commerce and the military, too. They had a huge influence not only on Tianhai but also on the whole country.

But Gu Jun had moved beyond all that. His metrics were different now. It was a lot deeper.

Once the Heaven-Encompassing Array was online, even high-stage cultivators would feel it. Their souls would quiver under its net. And even now, without it, he could break the Xiao family if he wanted to. Tianhai was his ground.

They would yield. Or they would fall.

And they weren't the only ones drifting from the path. There were governors. Generals. Corporate giants. People who'd once received his hand and were now slowly pulling away from it.

That, too, had been expected.

Let them fall away. Let them show their colors before the final move. For every one that strayed, dozens were waiting in the wings, hungrier, more loyal, more capable.

The Wild Universe had no use for pride dressed up as freedom.

And once Tianhai was secured, once the Xiao were reduced or removed, the path would stretch forward.

Toward Nator.

The capital.

The place where empires had risen and collapsed for centuries. The throat of the country. The center of everything. Soon, it would no longer be the crown of the old world. It would be the stepping stone for the next one.

And when it fell, it wouldn't be the end of his plan.

It would be the second checkpoint.

The Imperial sword had just begun to rise.

chapters.name: 4. Imperial Embers
chapters.content:
Gu Jun returned home in silence.

He placed his coat on the stand, moved through the quiet chambers, and completed a few idle tasks, absent-minded, habitual. Then, with a sigh that carried the weight of the Empire, he sat.

He lifted a porcelain cup, steam curling like spirit wisps from the surface. The tea was bitter and strong, his father's favorite.

After the final sip, he reached for a small black case.

A click.

A flicker of flame, and the smoke was generated.

The imperial cigarette was lit.

It was a relic of sovereignty, one of the many legacies passed down from Qin Di, his silent, sealed predecessor. In the legends of the Wild Universe, only those of the Emperor’s Blood dared to inhale its power. Though others had smoked through pipes carved from celestial jade or incense bowls shaped from moonstone, Gu Jun rejected such tradition.

He preferred modernity. A steel cylinder, simple and clean.

After all, it was not the vessel, but the essence that mattered.

This cigarette, unlike anything found in the mundane world, was crafted from rare sky-herbs and powdered flood dragon horn. Its scent was sweet yet wild, floral notes wrapped in something ancient and untamed. It wasn’t just a vice. It was a ritual. It was an identity.

It was said to enhance one’s masculinity and grace, a symbol of command passed down for millions of years.

When the imperial cigarette is lit, something within Gu Jun shifts.

By outward appearance, he is unremarkable. Standing at 5'9", with a face that blends easily into a crowd, he’s the kind of man one might pass on the street and forget within moments. Nothing is striking about his looks, nothing that demands attention. He doesn’t radiate charisma or project dominance, at least, not at first glance.

But the moment he inhales that first curl of smoke, the air around him thickens with something intangible. His gaze sharpens, posture straightens, and presence expands. It’s as if an invisible crown settles on his head, and the weight of destiny aligns behind his eyes.

In that moment, Gu Jun is no longer ordinary. He becomes unreachable, a sovereign cloaked in silence, radiating the quiet pressure of command. A man not shaped by the world, but preparing to shape it in return.

Gu Jun leaned back, smoke coiling through the dim light, and stared into the deepening dusk.

Five kilometers away, someone walked with purpose.

He moved slowly, but each stride carried him ten meters forward. His presence went unnoticed, not because he hid, but because the world simply refused to acknowledge him.

He looked to be around thirty. His face was carved with quiet purpose, an indifferent expression, and a thin scar cutting across his cheekbone. It told of violence endured, not declared.

He reached Gu Jun’s estate and stepped inside.

Without a word, he entered the inner hall, his indifferent expression changed, became respectful and devoted, and then he offered a measured bow. “Greetings, Your Highness.”

Gu Jun didn’t turn. The cigarette glowed between his fingers.

Since the coronation ceremony had yet to be held, Your Highness remained in the proper form.

Only after a pause did Gu Jun speak, his voice calm and commanding.

“What’s the update?”

“Everything is prepared,” the man replied respectfully. “The Planning Council has finalized the annexation strategy for Tianhai. These are the documents.”

He carefully placed the papers on the low marble table with precise hands.

This was Longwei, Sixth Elder of the Gu Empire. Chief Messenger. One of the Twelve Pillars. One of the ten people alive who knew the true identity of Gu Jun.

“Strike group?” Gu Jun asked without looking.

“Ready. Strike One has broken through to the peak of the initial-stage Innate. The other two remain at early Innate, no progress, but stable.”

Gu Jun nodded faintly. “The Xiao family?”

“We’ve identified three internal factions: one hostile, one loyal to us, and one undecided. Their power is evenly distributed. Our strategy is to support the loyalist faction and let them consume the rest from within.”

“How long?”

“Approximately four months.”

Gu Jun frowned slightly.

When he saw Gu Jun's frown, Longwei felt his heart suddenly stop, and tiny beads of sweat began to form on his forehead.

“Hmm, longer than expected. But we must do it cleanly. No mistakes."

Longwei let out a sigh of relief; he felt his heart start working again.

"And the formation?”

This time Longwei's eyes changed and became a lot more serious, and he replied, “Progressing well. We’ve located all but the final piece. Once it’s set, activation will take three months. After that, we will have full control over Tianhai.”

“Where’s the last piece?”

“Antarctica.”

The Heaven-Encompassing Array required multiple ancient components, each connected to ley lines buried deep in the Earth. The Gu Empire had secured them all, except one. Once integrated, the array would root itself into the planet’s core.

Gu Jun’s cigarette burned low, but the scent became sharper and sharper.

“And your cultivation?” he asked.

“I’m approaching the peak of mid-Innate. I expect to break through within weeks.”

“Good.” Gu Jun stood. “I leave for Tianhai tonight.”

Longwei replied respectfully, “We’ve prepared everything, Your Highness.”

Gu Jun gave a small wave. “You may go.”

Longwei bowed again. “Farewell, Your Highness.”

He left as quietly as he had come.

Gu Jun watched the door close behind him.

Longwei had once been one of twenty chosen not for wealth or lineage, but for something deeper. A rare convergence of potential and obedience. Each had been given resources and a unique cultivation method. Unlike the Xiao family and other pawns, these twenty were not tested.

They were forged.

Now, they stood as the Empire’s true core, powerhouses without peer, invisible giants holding up a kingdom born in shadow.

The room grew still.

Then, Gu Jun’s shadow twisted unnaturally across the floor, lengthening… expanding. It was really a weird site.

As the shadow became bigger, from its depths, two figures emerged.

A man and a woman, both appearing no older than twenty.

The male was quiet, his eyes cold and calculating. The female was his mirror opposite; vibrant, mischievous, eyes alight with curiosity and fire. Despite their stark contrast, they were twins, united by origin, divided by temperament.

Yingchen and Yinglan. The Twin Shadows of Gu Jun. Both were strikingly attractive and had followed Gu Jun for nearly six years. Once abandoned children, they were unlike others, given the best resources to rapidly cultivate strength. But that rapid rise came with a price. Their progress eventually slowed, and now both remained at the mid-Innate stage, strong, but stalled.

Although they were both Mid-Innate, their combined attack could kill a late-stage Innate. And if they used their surprise attack, combined their special skill, and their Super Innate weapon, they could heavily injure a peak Innate.

“Master,” Yinglan said, stretching her arms dramatically. “I’m so bored. When are we going to Tianhai? I am telling you that after we go to Tianhai, you have to let me play more frequently.”

Gu Jun smiled; a rare flicker of warmth could be seen in his eyes, and he reached out to tousle her hair.

She was the only soul in the world who received such treatment from him. Not even the elders dared such closeness.

Not yet.

chapters.name: 5. Beneath the Silence
chapters.content:
Gu Jun then stepped into the inner chamber of the house.

It was quiet here, a place untouched by time. He moved to the window, letting his gaze settle on the far horizon where the sky kissed the earth. The late light slanted across the floor, casting long shadows, echoes of the weight in his heart.

He spoke aloud, though no one else seemed present.

"I'm confused," he murmured. “I can’t help but feel... I’m the reason my master died. If he hadn’t broken the seal for me, he might still be alive. It feels... unfair.”

To a passerby, it would have seemed he was talking to himself. But in the stillness, something shifted.

From the air itself, like a ripple through unseen dimensions, a silhouette emerged.

It had no face, no body. Only the faint, shifting outline of a humanoid form, flickering like smoke at the edge of reality. A being not bound by the physical world. To behold it was to feel awe or dread.

Then it spoke. Its voice was not heard with the ears, but felt in the bones.

“Even without the attack, your master would not have lived long. Remember, you were nearly twelve when the seal broke. Enlightenment was near. And at that moment, his death was inevitable.”

A pause.

“Had we wished it, those pitiful assassins would never have reached you. But your master believed it unnecessary. He chose the sacrifice.”

“Hmm…” Gu Jun gave a soft, hollow sound, his eyes still distant.

The silhouette continued, its tone ancient and firm.

“You must not linger in guilt. Focus now on your path, your mission. I have existed far longer than you can comprehend. So long, I sometimes forget who I once was. But I have witnessed such sacrifices before. Rare, yes, but not unknown. He gave his life to fulfill his vow. One day, you may have to do the same. That is the burden of power.”

The air grew heavier as it spoke.

“Never forget your responsibility to this universe, to humanity, and to the legacy that shaped you. You carry not only your master’s hopes but the grace of generations.”

This shadowed figure was Xuanzhi, one of Gu Jun’s greatest inheritances from Qin Di.

More than a relic, Xuanzhi was an ancient construct, a soul fragment carved from the Black Tortoise, a sacred beast whose consciousness had endured for over a hundred million years. Neither ghost nor machine, Xuanzhi was a sentient echo of immense age, gifted with memory, wisdom, and unshakable loyalty.

For thirty generations of Qin Emperors, he had served silently as an advisor, archivist, and unseen guardian.

Despite his otherworldly presence, Xuanzhi held no combat strength of his own. He could shift through space, vanish into shadow, move between dimensions, but these gifts came with limits. Excessive use would drive him into a deep slumber. And more importantly, he was bound to Gu Jun’s proximity, unable to travel far from his sovereign.

These limitations, however, were temporary. As Gu Jun’s power grew, so too would Xuanzhi’s freedom.

It was during one of Qin Di’s final lucid moments, after Gu Jun’s birth, that he released Xuanzhi, setting the last threads of his vast design into motion.

And now, that design was unfolding.

Xuanzhi’s voice softened.

“Live a human life where you can—even if only in fragments. Your father wished that for you. He knew your burden, even if not in full. He did not want it to crush you too early.”

“You are well-trained, but still young. This is the age of confusion, of passion, of impulse. Tread carefully, Gu Jun. Your path demands it.”

Gu Jun nodded silently.

Fifteen years ago.

A village forgotten by the capital, nestled at the edge of the country.

It was a time when law and order had begun to stretch their arms, promising justice and stability. In the heartlands, laws were enforced, criminals were punished, and people started to believe in peace.

But the borders, those frayed edges of civilization, were a different world entirely.

There, the law thinned like mist in the morning sun. Power belonged to whoever held a blade and the will to use it. Raiders, mercenaries, and exiles crossed from neighboring lands, their hearts untouched by treaties or fear of reprisal. To them, the border wasn’t a wall; it was an open wound waiting to be exploited.

On that day, in one such village, a boy named Lin Mo played in the dust.

He was two and a half years old.

The sky was overcast, the sun hidden behind layers of dull gray clouds. He sat near the doorway of his home, shaping little mounds of dirt into towers with his tiny fingers. His mother worked nearby, humming softly. Her presence made the world feel whole.

Then the silence was shattered.

There were shouts and screams.

Strangers burst into the village, men with hardened faces and cold eyes, bearing weapons soaked in rust and blood. They came not for conquest, but for carnage. What followed wasn’t war, it was slaughter.

They moved through the village like wildfire. Men were cut down mid-task. Women begged. Children cried. None were spared. Even livestock were butchered, not from need, but from cruel delight.

Lin Mo had no words for what he saw, only images burned into his mind forever. His father’s voice shouted from the fields. The neighbor who gave him sweets, an axe buried in the old man’s chest.

His mother didn’t run. She grabbed him, pulled him to her chest, shielding his tiny body with her own. Her heartbeat thundered against his ear.

Then came the spear.

He remembered the grunt she made, sharp, short, as it pierced her back. Her arms tightened for one final second, as if her last act of will was to protect him.

Then… silence.

The raiders assumed she was dead, and Lin Mo with her.

They moved on.

After the slaughter, they looted everything, grain, tools, jewelry, even a few surviving girls and children, dragged away screaming. Then they set fire to the homes, watching with amusement as flames devoured roofs and memories.

Before leaving, they gathered the dead. Corpses were thrown into a wide pit at the center of the village.

Lin Mo, still wrapped in his mother’s lifeless embrace, was thrown in with them.

He didn’t cry. He didn’t scream. Maybe the shock had locked his voice away. Or maybe, even then, something deep inside understood:

Noise brings death.

For six long hours, he lay in that grave.

The heat from the fires. The stench of burnt hair and flesh. The weight of bodies pressing down, sickening, yet oddly warm. Even as a toddler, the memory etched itself deep into his soul.

The blood was soaking into his skin.
The cold stillness of his mother’s arms.
The face of the man who killed her; calm, almost bored.

He would never forget.

Something inside Lin Mo died that day.

chapters.name: 6. Three Blades for the Throne
chapters.content:
Six Hours Later

Lin Mo was barely conscious.

Six hours had passed since the massacre, and every moment had been a slow descent into darkness. His tiny body, still nestled in the arms of his dead mother, was numb, his skin soaked in blood, his senses dulled by smoke and silence. He was cold. Hungry. His vision blurred and dimmed.

Then he heard footsteps.

A shadow appeared at the edge of the pit. It was a figure of a boy, maybe fifteen, standing and looking down with sharp eyes and a strange calm. He wore black robes, neat and unstained. His silver hair gleamed even in the ash-covered air.

Lin Mo was saved that day, though he wouldn’t understand the cost until many years later.

Present Day – Unknown Location

Lin Mo awoke with a start; his body was covered in sweat, breath sharp, heart pounding.

It was that nightmare again. The one that returned like clockwork, screams, blood, the dead stares of his mother and father. He rubbed his eyes and sat up. The bed was stiff, the room cold, and dimly lit by the lantern's glow.

Outside, the morning drills had begun. He stepped onto the balcony of the fortress-like structure. Below, disciples meditated in rows, their breaths synchronized like a tide.

Fifteen years had passed since that day.

Lin Mo was now nearly eighteen, no longer the boy who cried in a grave of corpses. He had been forged in shadow and trained in silence. His body bore scars that no healer could erase, and his mind was sharp, hardened like tempered steel.

The man who saved him all those years ago was no ordinary rescuer. He was LongChen, the Left Protector of the Gu Empire, one of the three most powerful cultivators in the empire.

He is the unseen shield of the empire, the one who guards from the shadows.

Every covert operation, every silent mission, every whisper in the dark answers to him.

Be it the Dark Guards, the Hunters, or the spies and assassins, he commands every force that moves unseen, safeguarding the empire from within and without.

LongChen was also Lin Mo’s master.

A soft, near-silent sound of footsteps approached. Lin Mo turned. He recognized the pattern immediately; it was like the footfall of a hunter stalking prey.

LongChen entered, dressed as always in black. His features were perfect, symmetrical, unnervingly handsome, yet somehow false, as though sculpted rather than born. His silver hair shimmered with unnatural sheen.

No matter how long Lin Mo had known him, he had never been able to read the man. There was always a layer he couldn’t reach, a depth he couldn’t fathom.

“You’re awake,” LongChen said, voice low and calm.

“Yes.”

“How is your realm consolidation?”

“Complete,” Lin Mo replied. “Stable and solid.”

He had broken through to the Innate Realm days ago. Since then, he had spent every hour stabilizing his new power. The process had been agonizing, but necessary. Now, he was ready.

LongChen nodded. “Good. That means you’re ready. No mistakes. No shame to my name.”

There was an unusual gravity in his tone. LongChen was always serious, but today, something else lingered behind his words. A weight.

Lin Mo noticed. “Is something wrong?”

“No,” LongChen said. “But you’re about to receive your most important mission to date.”

He paused. Then he added with unusual gravity in his tone, “His Highness is coming to Tianhai. You will be one of his three personal guards.”

Lin Mo froze. The moment had come.

He had trained for this day, endured brutal drills, impossible trials, and years of shadow warfare. Now, he would finally serve beside the Emperor’s chosen, not as a servant, but as one of his silent blades.

He understood the structure. There would be three guards:

The leader of the Light Guards, a peer around his age, was known for his bright demeanor and transparent tactics. He served openly and was the face of protection, always visible, always smiling. His master is the Right Protector of the Empire, another titan in cultivation and authority.

The Dark Guard, shadow-bound and ever-present, would never leave the Emperor’s side. No matter what happened, even under direct attack, they were never to retreat. To do so would mean exposing the Emperor to danger.

Then there was the Hunter, Lin Mo’s role.

He would strike when others fell. He would pursue fleeing enemies, execute the Emperor’s will, and serve as the executioner in darkness. If a threat appeared, Lin Mo would be the blade that silenced it.

Swift. Silent. Deadly.

A role for which he had been sculpted since childhood.

“Your cultivation is still low compared to the others,” LongChen said bluntly, “but it will suffice for now.”

Lin Mo exhaled. He knew that. The head of the Light Guard was nearing mid-Innate. The head of the Dark Guard, An Jing, was already there. Lin Mo was only at the initial stage of Innate. He was the weakest among them.

“Be ready. Your mission begins tomorrow.”

“Yes, Master.” Lin Mo hesitated, then asked, “What about An Jing?”

“He’s already in Tianhai,” LongChen replied.

“...I see.”

Just the name sent a chill down Lin Mo’s spine.

He had seen LongChen fight only once, during the destruction of his village. It was a long time ago.

But he had seen An Jing in action more than once in recent times.
And each time, it was terrifying.

Both Dark Guards and Hunters trained similarly, but An Jing’s strikes had a ruthless precision that Lin Mo feared he might never match.

“Resolve any personal matters tonight,” LongChen said, turning to leave.

“I will.”

Lin Mo watched his mentor vanish into the corridor.

He did have one personal matter to handle.

And it couldn’t wait.

chapters.name: 7. A Train Toward Fate
chapters.content:
Soon, Lin Mo was ready to settle a long-overdue personal matter.

It wasn’t something particularly grand, not a war or political mission. It was just vengeance. Simple, personal vengeance. He was going to kill the man who had murdered his mother.

Fifteen years ago, when LongChen had descended upon the raiders that destroyed Lin Mo's village, he had intentionally spared one man, the killer of his mother. He left that man alive, beaten and broken, not out of mercy, but so Lin Mo could take justice into his own hands when the time was right.

Over the years, Lin Mo had confronted him six times. Each time, he inflicted unimaginable damage, leaving the man teetering between life and death. If Lin Mo had truly wanted to end it, he could have done it very easily. But he didn’t. It was a cruel game of cat and mouse, a slow, calculated torment.

But now the game has lost its thrill.

Now, it will end. Lin Mo had no patience left for mercy or hesitation.

At the central train station of the city, Gu Jun arrived. Here he will board a train for Tianhai.

To the average onlooker, he was alone, just another well-dressed youth preparing for a journey. But appearances were deceptive. Four people accompanied him, though almost no one would be able to spot them if they did not want to.

The first was An Jing, who had arrived separately to rendezvous. The other two were Yingchen and Yinglan, his shadows. And then there was the last, a masked woman, around twenty-four years old.

She was Di Yan, the personal bodyguard sent by Gu Jun’s mother.

Zi Feng believed her son was living a normal life, preparing for university. She had no idea about his current complicated situation. Six years ago, during the assassination attempt, all of the Zi family’s elite guards were slaughtered. Unaware of the true events, Zi Feng assumed the guards had protected her son successfully. So she also concentrates on taking revenge. And she was successful in taking control of the family.

Following that incident, Di Yan had been assigned to watch over Gu Jun. Once a junior apprentice within the Zi family’s inner guard, she was now his designated protector.

Though she lived in close proximity to him, she knew very little about his true situation. Gu Jun didn’t worry about her discovering anything. LongChen had arranged things carefully, ensuring her loyalty, even from his own mother.

Despite her limited understanding of the situation, Di Yan was no ordinary guard. Her cultivation had reached the peak of the Dark Energy stage. Though Gu Jun considered it weak compared to his other companions, her strength was formidable by ordinary standards.

In an open field, she was nearly untouchable. Her agility and stealth made her almost impossible to catch. In a confined space, it would take a platoon of at least twenty well-armed soldiers with automatic rifles to bring her down. Even then, it wouldn't be easy. In the open, one would need machine guns just to slow her.

Earth’s cultivation stages were structured, but unforgiving.

The first stage was Vitality Sensation, the gateway to cultivation. It enhanced physical ability five to ten times; strength, speed, and reflexes, just enough to outperform normal humans.

Next came Bright Energy, where one could channel vitality outward. Practitioners could leap from five-story buildings, bend metal with their bare hands, and dodge bullets.

Dark Strength followed. Di Yan was currently at its peak. Here, practitioners could move with blinding speed, coat weapons in energy, and unleash ranged attacks of pure vitality. Telekinesis, enhanced senses, and energy projection became possible. Lifespan extended to roughly 150 years.

Then came HuaJin, a stage few reached. To kill a HuaJin-level warrior required a company of at least two hundred elite soldiers with advanced weaponry. A single one could level a city block if provoked. The most powerful families might possess only a handful. For instance, the Xiao family had just seven HuaJin warriors. Their patriarch stood at the peak of this realm, with a lifespan nearing 225 years.

Above that loomed Innate, a realm where cultivators transcended the limits of the body and became forces of nature. Even the prestigious Zi family had only three Innate-level warriors, including their ancient patriarch, who was said to have reached the late stage.

In Country X, reaching the peak of Innate carried a heavy consequence: banishment from the mundane realm. Anyone breaking through was sent to the Sacred Garden, a hidden place where the nation's most powerful beings, the Supreme Protectors, resided in silence. They were barred from interfering in mortal affairs. They are too dangerous, too powerful. So they are also called the Humanoid calamities.

The country is very careful about them. Those people are humanoid disasters; only a nuclear weapon is effective against them, but it is not a complete sure kill, as they can hide themselves in the deeper dimension.

There were four known Peak Innates in Country X.

In the Gu Empire, there were three: the Right Protector, the Left Protector, and the Grand Elder.

It has a lifespan of 400 years, and most of Country X’s peak innates are old monsters.

Their only duty is to provide stability to the country and attempt to break through to the Divine Stage, a cultivation realm that has not appeared for thousands of years. It is said that Divine Stage warriors can leave Earth and travel to other planets in the solar system, but this remains uncertain, as no one has ever seen one. They are a mystery to others, but clearly not to Gu Jun.

Gu Jun boarded the train.

He stepped into a first-class compartment, noting that there were only ten passengers inside. Quiet. Perfect.

As he sat by the window, his thoughts turned inward, toward his own cultivation. Currently, he lingered at the bottom: Vitality Sensation. It was pitifully weak compared to what he needed to become.

He longed to improve. However, his path was unlike that of others. His breakthrough was harsh, nearly impossible without meeting certain conditions.

And those conditions, unfortunately, were beyond his control, at least for now.

chapters.name: 8. Senior Sister's Protection
chapters.content:
Gu Jun sat quietly in the first-class train compartment.

The train hadn’t departed yet, and just a few minutes remained before the journey began.

There were not many people on the first-class side of the train.

Suddenly, the screech of tires broke the calm environment. A sleek black SUV pulled up just outside the station entrance. From it stepped two high-heeled young women, both strikingly beautiful. Trailing them were two well-built men in black suits, and by the look of them, they were bodyguards.

Gu Jun glanced at the bodyguards casually. In an instant, their cultivation levels appeared in his mind: peak of Bright Strength.

They followed the women into the first-class compartment and took their seats behind them. The two girls, meanwhile, sat directly across from Gu Jun.

Even Gu Jun had to admit, they were stunning. The kind of beauty that turned heads without effort. The girls gave him a brief look before turning away, uninterested.

That, too, was expected. Gu Jun’s appearance was average at best, despite his remarkably good-looking parents. There was nothing remarkable in his face to draw their attention.

He didn’t care. However, his indifference made the girls glance at him again, just briefly, with faint curiosity. They were accustomed to admiration, not quiet disregard.

Unbothered, Gu Jun pulled a worn paperback from his bag and began reading. The carriage fell into a comfortable hush.

The warmer, more outgoing of the two girls broke the silence first.

She said excitedly, “Cousin, wasn’t that vacation great? I told you that this place has the perfect balance of natural scenery and urban life.”

Her cousin, colder and more reserved, nodded slightly. “It was nice.”

“Come on, cousin, don’t be so stingy with your words,” she teased. “But you have to admit, it was the perfect break before the new semester.”

They kept chatting softly. Gu Jun didn’t listen. His focus was on the words on the page.

Just then, three more people entered the compartment.

One was a tall, handsome young man with a practiced smile. The other two were clearly his bodyguards.

The man’s gaze swept the room before freezing in surprise as he spotted the two girls.

Even a child could see he was faking it.

He strode over, all confident swagger.

“Bai Yue! What a coincidence,” he said with forced enthusiasm. “Didn’t expect to see you on this train.”

The cold girl, Bai Yue, barely reacted. But her cousin narrowed her eyes.

“Wang Wei, cut the act. We all know you’re stalking us. It’s creepy.”

Wang Wei grinned, undeterred. “You can think that if you like. But I’m not stalking you. I’m here for your cousin. It’s rare for someone like me to take time for someone, shouldn’t that show you how serious I am?”

“Or how much of a pervert you are,” Rong Xi snapped.

“Hey now, don’t slander me,” he shot back, still smiling. Then, turning to Bai Yue with a softer tone, “Since fate brought us together, why not talk a bit to pass the time?”

“I have no time to pass,” Bai Yue said flatly. “Go and find your seat.”

Wang Wei’s smile vanished. He turned his attention to Gu Jun.

“You. Get up. Go and sit somewhere else.”

Gu Jun didn’t even glance at him.

Wang Wei frowned. “I said, get up.”

Finally, Gu Jun looked up, calm and expressionless. “I’m not moving. You should find another seat.”

Wang Wei pulled out a stack of bills and tossed them toward Gu Jun.

“Take this. Go and sit somewhere else. I want to talk with these ladies, we are familiar.”

Rong Xi scoffed. “We’re not that familiar.”

Gu Jun blinked, baffled. Was this actually happening? It felt like a cliché from a bad soap opera, yet here it was, unfolding in real time, and he was also involved.

Then, to his surprise, Rong Xi turned to him and ordered, “Don’t move. Stay right there.”

Gu Jun let out a faint laugh. He could tell these three all came from prominent families.

“Alright,” he said with a small smile. “I’m not going anywhere.”

Wang Wei’s face darkened. “You’re making a mistake.”

His bodyguards stepped forward.

Suddenly, Gu Jun felt the air shift. Heavy. Dangerous.

Di Yan was reacting.

Though she sat quietly nearby, masked and restrained, her presence surged. If she attacked, no one in the room, not even the bodyguards, would leave unscathed. They wouldn’t die, but they’d regret their decision to take action.

Bai Yue gave Wang Wei a sharp glare. She turned and signaled her own bodyguard.

The man stepped forward, tension in his stance.

“Wang Wei,” she said coldly, “don’t make a scene. It won’t end well for you.”

Wang Wei hesitated. Then, as if remembering something, he backed off.

He looked at Gu Jun and said with forced calm, “We’ll meet again.”

Then he turned and walked into the next compartment, his bodyguards trailing behind.

Gu Jun exhaled softly. Inwardly, he thought, You were one second away from getting destroyed.

Rong Xi grinned and turned to him. “Hey, you were brave. I’m Rong Xi from Tianhai. I am studying at Tianhai Royal University. What’s your name? Where are you from?”

“Gu Jun,” he replied. “Freshman. Also Tianhai Royal University.”

“Ohhh! So you’re my junior! Hurry up and call me ‘Senior Sister’!”

Gu Jun looked at her with a dry expression. “Senior Sister.”

“Haha, good!” she laughed. “Stick with me, little brother. I’ll protect you!”

“Okay, Senior Sister.”

Bai Yue looked at them with faint surprise, then turned to Gu Jun. “Be careful of Wang Wei. He’s not harmless. He’s also from Tianhai Royal University.”

Gu Jun nodded, his expression unreadable. The lack of emotion in his response made Bai Yue glance at him twice.

Rong Xi snorted. “He won’t dare mess with my junior. I’ll break his leg.”

Bai Yue gave her cousin a side glance and said, “Don’t act so aggressively all the time. You’re a girl, remember?”

Rong Xi shrugged with a grin. “Being a 'good girl' is boring.”

Gu Jun observed them quietly. It was becoming more and more clear that once she let her guard down, Rong Xi was anything but calm.

Just then, the sharp sound of the train’s horn comes from the front.

A moment later, the train began to move.

chapters.name: 9. Tianhai Crossroads
chapters.content:
The train roared along the tracks, cutting through the countryside like a silver dragon. Inside, Gu Jun sat by the window, watching the blurry greens and browns of the landscape fly past. His reflection shimmered faintly on the glass; calm, collected, almost detached.

Across from him, Rong Xi was still talking; cheerful, animated, and unstoppable. She had no problem filling the silence with conversation, even when no one asked for it.

"I'm in my third year now," she was saying. "Business Administration. Honestly, it's boring, but I’ll probably inherit part of the family business, so it can’t be helped."

Gu Jun listened politely, occasionally nodding, though his attention shifted to Bai Yue, who sat quietly beside her cousin. She was the opposite in every way; composed, elegant, and radiating an air of quiet pride. He hadn't expected her next words.

“I’ve just joined the university,” she said calmly. “As a lecturer. English Department.”

That stunned him more than it should have. A lecturer? At such a young age?

Rong Xi rolled her eyes. “Don’t let her fool you. She just finished her master’s and got pulled in immediately. She’s always been the overachiever in the family.”

As the train continued its journey, Gu Jun caught snippets of their conversation, two names standing out like thunder in a clear sky: Rong Family. Bai Family.

He closed his eyes briefly, recalling what he knew about Tianhai's power structure.

The Xiao family sat at the top, unquestioned and unrivaled, with wealth and influence stretching into politics, business, and even the criminal underworld.

Beneath them were five recognized first-class families. The Rong family, famous for their grip on real estate, ranked first among these. The Bai family, wealthy from their international trade empire, held the third spot. Combined, their estimated worth exceeded 600 billion yuan.

Then he thought of Wang Wei as well. That arrogant young master from earlier had to be from the Wang family, a name that surfaced often in both business and darker dealings. On the surface, they owned chains of casinos, entertainment hubs, and resorts. Beneath that glittering exterior, they ran the Green Gang, the second-most powerful underworld gang in Tianhai.

The number one gang? That belonged to the Xiao family, controlling a full 60% of the city’s underworld.

The remaining 40% was split between the Green Gang and the Imperial Bull Gang, controlled by the Hong family, a relatively new power. Though fresh to the game, the Hong family had risen meteorically. Gu Jun knew why; the Gu Empire backed them completely. Word in the planning council was clear: if the Xiao family went rogue, the Hong family would become Tianhai’s new ruling clan.

This plan, of course, was gradual and had some calculation and complication, but the direction was firm.

Gu Jun also recalled that elements of the Rong family had been quietly aligning themselves with Gu Empire-friendly factions, hinting at deeper cooperation.

As the train neared Tianhai Central Station, the compartment buzzed with movement. Passengers gathered their belongings, standing up and adjusting coats and bags. Bai Yue gently closed her tablet. Rong Xi yawned and stretched, her energy finally dimming.

When the train came to a halt, the trio stepped out into the warm summer air.

They said their goodbyes with polite formality; after all, they would inevitably meet again at Tianhai Royal University.

Once alone, Gu Jun pulled out his phone and dialed Uncle Tang.

He was a close friend of his father, and Gu Jun suspected that Tang’s smooth rise through the government bureaucracy was due to his mother, Zi Feng. He had always treated Gu Jun with genuine warmth.

“Uncle Tang,” Gu Jun said when the call connected. “I’ve arrived.”

“I’ll be there soon,” Tang replied. “Don’t go far.”

Gu Jun nodded to no one and began crossing the plaza in front of the station. Then he heard shouting behind him.

“Hey! Boy! Stop!”

He turned and saw Wang Wei, flanked by his two bodyguards, storming out of the station and rushing across the road toward him. Their expressions were hostile, full of righteous indignation, and bruised ego.

Then it happened.

From a nearby underground parking garage, a heavily modified SUV, painted matte black, with tinted windows that reflected nothing, burst out with a deep growl.

It moved like a predator straight toward Wang Wei.

The bodyguards froze.

“Young Master! Look out!” one yelled.

One guard rushed to block the vehicle with his body, a desperate move, but the only one he had. The other tried to shield Wang Wei.

It was useless.

The SUV hit the first guard and launched him ten meters into the air. Bones cracked audibly. The second guard and Wang Wei were swept aside like bowling pins. They landed in a heap by the roadside, screaming in pain. Blood dripped from cuts and open fractures.

People nearby screamed.

But Gu Jun wasn’t looking at them.

He was looking at the taillights of the disappearing vehicle. Or more precisely, hearing something.

A soft, wicked laugh.

Rong Xi.

She had been waiting. Waiting to see if Wang Wei would try something stupid, and she had acted first.

Reckless, dangerous, and audacious.

Gu Jun smirked. She had truly taken her self-declared role as senior sister seriously. Though her family held power, attacking the Wang heir so openly would certainly provoke a response. But Gu Jun wasn’t worried. If needed, someone in the Gu Empire would handle the backlash. If the Wang family tried to escalate things... they'd be reminded where the true line of power lay.

From the pavement, Wang Wei and his guards looked at the disappearing SUV, then at Gu Jun with unmistakable hatred.

They knew who had triggered this humiliation.

A horn.

A sleek government car pulled up beside Gu Jun. The rear door opened, and a man in his fifties stepped out, dressed in a crisp summer suit.

“Well, look at you,” he said with a grin. “I haven’t seen you in two years, and now you’re already in university. Time flies.”

“Hello, Uncle,” Gu Jun greeted with a slight nod. “I’m doing well.”

“Good. Don’t stand around in the sun. Let’s get in.”

Inside the car sat a young girl, no older than fifteen, wearing a school uniform and earbuds. She eyed Gu Jun with mild curiosity.

“Gu Jun, meet my youngest daughter, Tang Xin,” Uncle Tang said. “Tang Xin, say hello to your brother.”

Tang Xin looked at him, scrutinized him head to toe, then said bluntly, “I haven’t seen you in two years. I thought you’d grow up handsome. But you’re still just... ordinary.”

Gu Jun blinked.

“Another spicy girl,” he thought, amused.

And with that, the car pulled into the bustling streets of Tianhai, a city of dynasties, ambition, and dangerous games.

chapters.name: 10. Uncle Tang's House
chapters.content:
Tianhai City shimmered outside the car window like a jewel carved into steel and glass.

Gu Jun leaned back in his seat, eyes fixed on the vibrant blur of lights, people, and skyscrapers that stretched endlessly into the horizon. Towering buildings gleamed in the afternoon sun, their reflections mirrored on the polished roads. The city pulsed with energy, wealth, ambition, and hidden tension. A far cry from the quiet countryside where he spent most of his childhood.

From the driver’s seat, Uncle Tang’s voice broke the silence.

“When do your university classes start?”

Gu Jun blinked, shifting his gaze. “The day after tomorrow.”

Uncle Tang nodded thoughtfully. “And your accommodation? You know, you’re always welcome to stay with us. But if you'd prefer the university hostel for more independence, that’s fine too.”

Gu Jun smiled faintly. “Thank you, Uncle. I’ll probably stay at the hostel most of the time, but I’ll visit often. I might even rent a small place near campus later on.”

Uncle Tang grunted in approval. “Good. Still, don’t worry too much about it, I’ve already made arrangements.”

Gu Jun wasn’t surprised. It had his mother’s touch written all over it. She must have discussed every possible scenario with Uncle Tang.

He turned to the girl beside him. “So, how’s your day going, Tang Xin?”

From beside him, Tang Xin stretched with a theatrical sigh. “Ugh. My day’s been so boring. I’m not allowed to go out alone. All my friends are running wild while I’m stuck at home like some tragic heroine.”

She turned to him suddenly, her eyes gleaming with mischief. “But now that you’re here, Gu Jun, things are going to change. Your main job from today is to keep me entertained. I’ll show you what real fun means.”

Uncle Tang glanced at her through the rearview mirror with an annoyed expression.

“Hey, old man,” she teased, “don’t give me that look. I finally have a trusted male companion. You can’t stop me from enjoying life anymore.”

Gu Jun chuckled. “I’m fine with that, as long as Uncle and Aunt Tang approve.”

“Hah! See? You’re not as useless as you look!” she grinned.

“Be polite,” Uncle Tang said dryly.

The car pulled into the driveway of a large, elegant house in the quieter residential district of Tianhai. Inside, the air was cool and scented faintly with jasmine. Two maids stood at attention near the door. Aunt Tang greeted them with a polite smile, but her gaze toward Gu Jun was formal.

“It’s been a long time,” she said. “How are you? I heard you got into Tianhai Royal University. That’s quite an accomplishment. If your parents were alive… they would have been very proud.”
