Locking onto Longyun’s aura with his divine sense, he moved swiftly through the ruined underwater landscape to reach him.

Longyun was nearly unconscious.

He picked up Longyun and began searching for the array piece.

Longyun, through divine sense, told him that the array piece was in the space ring. Just after conveying this, he lost consciousness completely.

Code Z quickly checked on him. Although Longyun’s condition was critical, it wasn’t life-threatening.

With no time to waste, Code Z lifted Longyun and made his way to the surface, then started running through the ice.

Though Antarctica was a barren continent, it held immense resources beneath the ice, so inevitably, various countries maintained a military presence.

After running nearly five kilometers, Code Z suddenly sensed a disturbance in the air. Being highly experienced, he immediately recognized it; it was Eagletron, one of the most advanced fighter planes from Country B, capable of vertical landing.

Code Z knew all too well that several military camps from different nations were stationed nearby. It was impossible to conceal the explosion from them; they had detected it and were now moving in to investigate.

He had to move fast and do it while carrying Longyun.

After running for a while longer, he finally spotted the aircraft approaching. As it neared him, it began hovering overhead, scanning him carefully.

Then, it descended and landed on the ice.

After some time, four soldiers stepped out of the plane.

The pilot remained in the cockpit, and Code Z knew very well that the pilot’s finger was likely resting on the trigger of the plane’s weapon system.

They had to be cautious; they knew that Code Z was no ordinary person. Truth be told, under normal circumstances, Code Z wouldn’t have feared this plane. But now, things were different. He was carrying Longyun and protecting the mission.

The four soldiers surrounded him and demanded his identity.

Code Z calmly replied that he was from Country X and served in the military.

One of them stepped forward and said, “Show us your ID.”

In response, Code Z asked coldly, “Why should I show you? Who are you?”

Originally, Code Z had planned to get some help from these men. There would be complications, of course, but he believed he could handle them, even eliminate them, if necessary. But now, something had changed.

He felt a presence.

The soldiers were also stunned. They did not understand why this person suddenly became so aggressive.

Just as the soldiers were about to show a dominating attitude and prepared to threaten to use force, a sword sliced out from the white, snowy world.

Four strikes.

Four heads flew.

Four soldiers dropped dead.

It was a bloody scene. Crimson stained the pristine white ice, and the four severed heads rolled like grotesque blossoms, four vivid red flowers blooming on the frozen ground.

The attack was so sudden that there was still calmness in the soldiers’ eyes. Even in death, they had not seen it coming.

Clean. Ruthless. Silent.

Exactly what one would expect from the Empire’s Dark Guards.

Code Z now realized he should have anticipated this. Of course, the Dark Guards would trail them. This was a mission of critical importance, and an elder was directly involved. Moreover, the Dark Guards were notorious for being nosy; they were expected to follow missions like this, even from the shadows.

From the cockpit, the fighter pilot saw everything unfold. He immediately realized the danger. Panicked, he tried to lift the aircraft back into the air, and almost succeeded.

But then, another flash of sword light—

This sword strike was unusual, not aimed at the plane itself, but at the pilot. It was a mental sword strike, soft and precise. It slipped effortlessly into the cockpit like magic, bypassing the exterior without damaging the plane’s structure.

The pilot died instantly.

However, it wasn’t enough to stop the aircraft. This type of fighter had a powerful autopilot system that would automatically follow its pre-set flight path in such emergencies. So it flew away fast before the dark guards got the chance to take any more action to stop it.

Then, five figures emerged from the void like a tornado of wind.

They were the attackers, the Dark Guards of the Gu Empire. Each of them was at the HuaJin level, clad in the standard uniform of their order.

Code Z asked them, “How many of you are here?”

“You don’t need to know,” one replied coldly. “What you do need to know is, we’ve already sent someone to retrieve the item from the blast site. Also, stay alert. The danger isn't over.”

Just as he finished speaking, seven more figures appeared on the horizon.

Code Z turned his gaze and immediately recognized them, not ordinary soldiers, but Werewolves from the Werewolf Association. They, too, had a powerful military presence on the continent, and it was near the blast site.

Truly, human greed knows no bounds; everyone wants to get a piece of this frozen continent.

Truth be told, Code Z didn’t want to fight them. Why?

Because the Empire had been attempting to bring the Werewolves under its control for years, and recently, some progress had been made. These particular Werewolves might one day become valuable warriors for the Empire. They were an integral part of the Empire’s long-term strategic development plan.

After all, they were one of the two dominant forces of continent E and had powerful influence in the order of thirty-three.

The other?

The Vampires, of course.

As Code Z pondered this, the Werewolves reached the scene. True to their impulsive nature, they took one look at the severed heads on the ice and immediately launched an attack without any notice or conversation.

Code Z wanted to stop them.

But then he let out a long sigh.

Whatever.

From the insignias on their uniforms, emblazoned on their towering three-meter-tall wolf-headed hairy bodies, it was clear: these Werewolves weren’t from any tribe currently aligned with the Gu Empire.

If they wanted to die, so be it.

They were just too hot-headed.

chapters.name: 28. Chains, Crowns, and Cold Steel
chapters.content:
Soon, the Werewolves reached them.
They weren't speaking English, but some other language.
Then, they attacked.

They did not use any weapon; to them, their bodies were their best weapon. When they became enraged, they grew to almost four meters tall.

And then?

Another slaughter.

Although the Werewolves were greater in both number and size, they were ultimately only at the equivalent of the Dark Realm. So the inevitable happened.

They didn’t stand much of a chance.

Code Z understood this was due to their overconfidence and hotheaded nature.

He looked at these werewolves and thought, these bloody things, these foolish things, when will they be able to control their temper? Actually, they never learn. For these kinds of hotheadedness, they are always suppressed by the vampires.

From start to finish, they did not utter a word to them, nor did they ask anything, which only made the dark guards more enraged.

Since you people are so idiotic, die happily.

But then something else happened that left Code Z stunned. He instantly snapped out of his light mode.

From the sky, several small missiles dropped.

It was so sudden, and so silent, that even the Dark Guards were caught off guard. Their focus had been entirely on fighting the Werewolves. As a result, tragedy struck, and almost all of them were injured to some degree.

One of them was badly wounded in the leg; he was clenching his jaw strongly, trying not to let any painful sound come out of his mouth.

Then, from the far sky, two military helicopters came into view. These two helicopters were the culprits who threw the missile.

Code Z recognized the machines immediately, and their information came into his mind; they were from Country M: H3 helicopters, some of the deadliest military helicopters in the world. Especially designed for operations in extreme weather, they were perfectly suited to Antarctica.

These machines were the prized possessions of Country M’s military. They were export-banned; only Country M's forces were authorized to use them.

As soon as the choppers approached, bullets started flying.

These weren’t ordinary bullets; they were specially coated with uranium, making them dangerous even for HuaJin-level cultivators.

It was clear: Country M suspected that the explosion was related to cultivators, and that they might have recovered some valuable treasure from Antarctica. Unlike the team from Country B, they had come far more prepared.

Following the bullet barrage, a powerful projectile was launched, also designed specifically for cultivators. It exploded into uranium-coated splinters upon impact.

Code Z understood that these machines were using a super AI, although the dark guards were moving and evading the bullets with super-fast speed, the muzzles of the guns were always following them. These guns must use an excellent prediction algorithm.

From the looks of it, Country M had made their decision:

Kill first. Ask later.

After understanding this, the looks in the dark guard members' eyes became colder and more ruthless.

With the gunfire continuing, the members of the Gu Empire somehow managed to survive,
But all the remaining werewolves were killed.

Code Z looked at the Country M military personnel and their helicopters and let out a bitter smile.

As expected of Country M, they’re always so arrogant. No questions asked. Just fire.

Due to the ongoing barrage and the evasive maneuvers by the Dark Guards and Code Z, several massive holes had formed in the ice, revealing the frigid waters beneath.

To survive the bullets and rockets, some of the Dark Guards dove into the water.

This situation was even worse than when they had been attacked by the fighter jet from Country B. These helicopters were far more dangerous in close combat.

Code Z didn’t jump into the water. Why?

Because of Longyun.
He was already badly injured, and plunging into sub-zero temperature water would only make things worse, so jumping into the water would be the last resort.

Suddenly, a Dark Guard burst out of the water like a bullet.
He leapt high into the sky and, in an instant, reached the helicopter hovering nearly sixty meters above the ground.

As he closed in, he unleashed a deadly sword strike at the helicopter's rotors.

Code Z glanced up. He recognized him; it was likely the leader of the Dark Guards.

The sword light struck the base of the rotors with surgical precision, shattering them instantly.

The rotors, still spinning, flew off and crashed violently onto the ice.

Moments later, the helicopter itself seemed to realize its fate and followed suit, plummeting from the sky and slamming into the ground with a devastating explosion.

The blast fractured the ice, and freezing water spilled out in waves.

The Dark Guard who had attacked remained hovering mid-air, eyes scanning the sky for another opportunity to strike.
But the remaining helicopter had ascended, climbing higher, nearly two hundred meters, and no opening was left.

Code Z watched the wreckage below and couldn’t help but admit—

It was an exceptional attack.
Even for him, executing something like that would have been extremely difficult.

Clearly, the Empire had dispatched some of its finest Dark Guards.

Now, the other helicopter had grown more cautious.
It kept its distance and only launched occasional attacks from afar.

They had reached a stalemate.

This tale has been unlawfully lifted without the author's consent. Report any appearances on Amazon.

An impasse.

Code Z assessed the situation and turned to the Dark Guard leader, who had just landed nearby.

“Shouldn’t there be a Country X base here? From what I see, it looks like this copter has contacted its base and is waiting for reinforcements. Maybe you should consider using that mental strike again.”

The Dark Guard leader responded calmly,
“There are two Country X bases on this continent, but they’re a bit far from here. We didn’t inform them; this mission was top-secret from the start, so we never expected any assistance. That said, they might already know something’s going on. But don’t worry. We have a Dark Guard base hidden beneath the ice, and reinforcements are on their way. As for the mental strike… it consumes too much energy.

We could escape if we wanted to, but I’m staying. These soldiers attacked without warning, without asking a single question. We have to teach them a lesson. Bringing down both copters isn’t just about survival, it’s about the prestige of the Dark Guard.”

“Hmm,” Code Z muttered in agreement.

Meanwhile, skirmishes between the remaining helicopter and the Dark Guards continued.

Occasionally, the helicopter fired bullets and missiles. In response, streaks of sword light sliced through the sky from the Dark Guards.

Since the initial ambush, one Dark Guard had been badly injured. The others had only suffered minor wounds.

The severely injured guard remained underwater. Surfacing was too dangerous; his slowed movements could get him caught in the line of fire.

Code Z studied the scene and said with a frown,
“We should end this quickly. Other parties may arrive soon. It’s best if we leave.”

The Dark Guard leader gave a faint smile.

“Don’t worry. Our reinforcements have already arrived.”

Just as he finished speaking, a blinding beam of light streaked across the sky from afar and struck the helicopter directly. It moved so fast that even the highly advanced copter didn’t have a chance to evade.

From the glow and the force behind it, Code Z could tell that it was a powerful spiritual tool, possibly semi-innate, or even at the innate level.

This was likely the strongest weapon the Dark Guards possessed at their Antarctic base.

The blast tore a massive hole through the center of the helicopter.

Then came the explosion, loud, fiery, and final.

The entire unit was wiped out.

After some time, the battlefield quieted.

The situation was finally stabilized.

And then, Code Z saw the weapon that had struck the copter.

It was a silver spear, now floating motionlessly in the sky.

After a few moments, a man appeared.
He wasn’t running, just walking. But with every step he took, he covered nearly ten meters of distance, closing in swiftly and calmly.

He raised his hand toward the sky, and the spear flew directly into his grasp.

Walking over to Code Z, he asked,
“What’s the elder’s current condition?”

“He’s very weak, but not in a life-threatening state.”

“Good. Let’s go. We’ve retrieved everything important from the blast site. We also found the remains of Code B. He’s dead, obviously.”

“Yes, I knew.”

“Hmm.”

It was deep into the night.
Gu Jun was asleep.

But then, something strange happened.
He began to toss and turn in his sleep, his face twitching, his breath uneven.

From the outside, it looked like physical discomfort. But inside, he was dreaming, or perhaps, experiencing something more.

In his dream, he saw a platform.

But it wasn’t a normal platform. It was massive, so vast that he couldn’t see where it began or where it ended. The space felt surreal, almost maze-like, distorting all sense of scale.

And on that endless platform, he saw a person, although he could not see clearly; it should be a woman.

She was bound by hundreds of thousands of tiny chains, each forged from a strange, unknown material. The chains shifted constantly, sometimes tightening, sometimes twisting, and always moving.

Everything about them screamed restraint and containment.

On her head sat a black, blood-soaked crown. Her entire body was drenched in blood, and Gu Jun could see that the chains were absorbing it, feeding on it.

The blood seemed to power the chains, fueling their ability to hold her down.

Even though she was wounded and restrained, her aura was overwhelming.

Gu Jun didn’t know how strong she was, but he instinctively knew:
This was the most powerful person he had ever seen.

She stood motionless, her head bowed, eyes hidden beneath shadow.

And then, suddenly, she raised her head.

And looked directly at him.

Gu Jun froze.

In that instant, he made eye contact.

And something ancient, terrifying, and unfathomably deep stared back at him.

He was stunned, paralyzed in the dream world.

What kind of eyes were those?

They were cold, yet loving.
Ruthless, yet benevolent.
A paradox of emotions, shifting in every blink.

Gu Jun understood instantly—
This was the supreme mindset, supreme dao heart.
One thought to Buddha, one thought to the Devil.

Then the woman smiled, a strange, haunting smile.
Even though it was a dream, Gu Jun felt it in every fiber of his being.
His flesh went numb. His bones turned cold. He couldn’t move.

Then the woman spoke—
“Hehe… Tell me, boy. What is an Emperor?”

There was a sudden jolt.
Gu Jun snapped awake, his body drenched in sweat.

His heart pounded.
His eyes darted around.

He sat up, took a long breath, and muttered,
“That dream again…”

After some moments, he stood, walked out of the house, and crossed the empty street.
There, under the dark sky, he sat on a cold park bench, alone.

A strange sight, indeed:
A man, alone, on a bench, at this hour of night.

After a few moments of silence, Gu Jun spoke:
“What happened?”

A respectful voice answered from the shadows.
“Your Highness, we received a report from Antarctica.”

“Tell me everything.”

“Yes.”

And then Gu Jun listened, quiet and still, as every detail of the Antarctic incident was relayed.

When it was over, he asked,
“When will they arrive?”

“Tomorrow night. About 18 hours from now.”

“Alright. I’ll go. You may leave.”

“Your Highness…”

“I know. You go.”

“Farewell, Your Highness.”

Then that person vanished.
Disappeared into thin air without a sound.

That was Longwei, the messenger.

Gu Jun sat still, then slowly turned his gaze toward the far end of the park, into the dense shadows among the bushes.

He had known for a while…
Two people were hiding there.

He didn’t know when they’d arrived, but it didn’t matter.
They were assassins.
Not top-tier, but still competent, likely at the level of Bright Strength.

Gu Jun didn’t know who had sent them.
It could have been the Wang family,
Or the Xiao family,
Or even Ning Zhe himself.

All three had their hands in the Bai Yue affair, so all three had a reason to see him dead.

He had sensed them since last night, when they began tailing him through the streets.
They didn’t strike then, probably due to a lack of opportunity.

But now…

After that dream,
After the troubling report from Antarctica,
Gu Jun’s mind was weighed down, with frustration, unease, and the sting of loss.

An elder had been gravely injured. That alone was a heavy blow.

So now, he was offering them a chance.

A chance…
To kill him.

chapters.name: 29. When Death Calls
chapters.content:
Gu Jun slowly stood up.

He walked deeper into the park.

It was a community park attached to his residence, so it remained open at night.

Two assassins looked at him with mild surprise, as if wondering why someone would be strolling here at such an hour. Then, they smiled.

Wow, what a great opportunity. It’s true, when death calls, you subconsciously walk toward it.

Gu Jun smiled as well. He glanced at the two assassins. One was older, around forty, with a mustache. The other was younger, likely in his thirties, and his cultivation level was noticeably lower.

As Gu Jun continued walking deeper into the park, the two assassins silently followed him.

Gu Jun didn’t bother hiding his footsteps. As he walked, the crisp sound of dry leaves being crushed underfoot echoed softly in the still night air.

Then, suddenly, when he passed beneath the shadow of a tree, he vanished.

Some time later, the two assassins reached the spot where Gu Jun had disappeared.

They exchanged puzzled glances, then resumed searching the area.

As they looked around, a stone suddenly came flying out of nowhere and struck the younger assassin in the knee.

He stumbled and collapsed to the ground.

The older one turned toward him. “What happened? Why are you falling on your own?”

“I thought something hit me.”

“Nothing hit you. You just tripped over a tree root. You can’t even avoid that? Your quality is too low.”

Just as he finished speaking, another stone flew through the air, this time striking the older assassin.

Unlike his companion, the older one had far more experience. The moment the stone hit him, his instincts kicked in. He immediately became alert.

He scanned the surroundings carefully.

He recalled the information about the target; it was just a student from the countryside, supposedly with no combat experience. Someone like that shouldn't pose any threat.

Then who was throwing the stones?

As the two assassins moved forward again to search for Gu Jun, a slender tree branch suddenly flew in from a short distance. Its sharpened tip pierced the younger assassin’s leg, passing clean through. He dropped to the ground with a cry.

Before he could react, another stone came flying, this one much smaller. It struck his forehead with precision.

He didn’t even realize what had hit him before he died. A small, round hole appeared at the center of his forehead.

The older assassin immediately understood everything had gone wrong.

The target clearly wasn’t some ordinary student. He was a warrior. He might even have a cultivation level higher than his own.

Wasting no time, the older assassin stopped trying to investigate. There was no point looking, no point asking questions.

He turned and ran.

But before he could get far, a leg stretched out from the shadows.

He tripped over it and fell hard to the ground.

The leg, of course, belonged to Gu Jun.

He now stood over the assassin, gazing down at him with indifferent eyes.

Then he asked coldly, “So, tell me, who sent you?”

“Who are you? Your profile said you were just a normal person. But you clearly have high cultivation!”

“You don’t need to know. To be honest, you’re going to die today, that much is certain. But you should be happy. Normally, someone like you wouldn’t have the honor of dying by my hand. But today, I’m in a bad mood.”

“I don’t know who wants you dead! I just accepted the mission from a site online. Please, let me go!”

The moment he finished speaking, a thin branch shot out and stabbed into the soft part of his neck.

The truth was, Gu Jun didn’t really care who sent them. He could find out easily enough if he truly wanted to.

He looked at the bloody corpses of the two assassins.

It was true that he hadn’t killed many people in real life. But he had bathed in blood countless times within the virtual world of the training device. And that device, an extraordinary treasure, made everything feel terrifyingly real. In that world, he had become numb to killing.

Just to be sure, he pulled the branch from the assassin’s neck and examined his own reaction.

He waited to see if there was any discomfort… any guilt.

Nope, Nothing.

Those assassins had assumed he possessed a higher cultivation level than them. But that wasn’t the case. He was only at the Vitality Sensation level. However, thanks to his top-tier training and relentless effort, he could easily deal with them; he could see the flaws in their techniques and methods.

And with their mediocre cultivation methods, he could have taken them on even if they were at the Peak Bright Strength level, though it wouldn’t have been as easy as it was now.

He then slowly left the park and headed back to his house.

He needed to get some sleep; tomorrow was the first day of university life.

Morning.

Gu Jun woke up and went to the university.

As soon as he arrived, he noticed many luxurious cars, driven by both male and female students.

Gu Jun had come on a bicycle, making him stand out awkwardly among all those flashy vehicles.

Some students even looked at him with contempt.

Even walking was better than this; after all, this was Tianhai Royal University.

Huh. Materialistic society, he thought.

He left the parking area and entered his dormitory. All of his roommates were already there, getting ready for their first day.

As soon as he entered, nearly all of them looked at him with admiration. Especially Xiao Wei, he gazed at Gu Jun with worshipful eyes.

“Boss, you're on fire! You made Bai Yue your girlfriend yesterday, and you didn’t come back to the dorm last night. Where were you? Off getting some night action with the cold queen?”

“Don’t talk nonsense,” Gu Jun replied. “I was at my house, the one my family arranged for me.”

“Ohh, so you were at your house… with Bai Yue, right?”

Gu Jun lightly smacked Xiao Wei’s head. “No, I was alone.”

“Alone with Bai Yue, right?”

“No. I was completely alone.”

“Really? That’s hard to believe.”

Xiao Wei gave him a suspicious look.

“You’ll have to believe it, whether you want to or not. Now let’s go to the cafeteria. I’m starving.”

As soon as they stepped outside, they ran into Luo Yuxin, who had clearly been waiting for them.

The group then made their way to Cafeteria No. 1.

After everyone sat down, Luo Yuxin took the lead in ordering food, as she was the most familiar with the cafeteria's menu.

Gu Jun glanced between her and Zhao Ming, curiosity in his eyes.
“So... what’s your relationship? You two must have some history.”

Xiao Wei smirked and chimed in, “Yeah, tell him. We all know already, he’s the only one who doesn’t.”

Zhao Ming looked a little embarrassed. “We were childhood playmates. My mom was her nanny when she was little. Then we went to school together, learned piano together… During college, we started dating. When her family found out, they—”

“Okay, okay,” Gu Jun interrupted, waving his hand. “Sounds like a typical dog-blood love drama. So, you came to this university for her?”

“She’s definitely one of the reasons,” Zhao Ming admitted.

At last, Luo Yuxin turned to Gu Jun and said politely, “Sorry for the late introduction. I’m Luo Yuxin, Zhao Ming’s girlfriend.”

Gu Jun gave Zhao Ming a slight smile. Yesterday, this guy was checking out the girls on the top ten list. Maybe he wasn’t sure about her before.

Luo Yuxin, on the other hand, was quietly observing all of Zhao Ming’s roommates.
She hadn’t forgotten the events of the previous night.
She knew none of these boys were simple.

She spoke sincerely, “Thank you all for what you did last night. If you weren’t there, I don’t know what would’ve happened to me.”

Xiao Wei waved it off. “Forget it. That wasn’t just about you; it was a complicated situation. Anyway, now you’re our sister-in-law. Of course, we’ll protect you.”

Zhou Hao nodded in agreement. “Mhm.”

Gu Jun then turned to Zhou Hao and remarked, “You had a good fight yesterday. Looked like you were in rough shape… but today, you’ve recovered well.”

Zhou Hao’s expression turned slightly bitter.
He had paid a heavy price for that recovery.

Gu Jun could guess—Zhou Hao had clearly used a powerful and expensive healing pill. Without it, recovering so quickly from that kind of injury would’ve been impossible.

Gu Jun took a deep breath, subtly trying to catch the lingering scent…
Maybe he could identify the origin of the pill.

And just as he suspected, he caught the scent.
That pill had come from the Medicine God Sect.

They continued eating and laughing. The atmosphere was light and harmonious.

But it didn’t last.

Suddenly, heavy footsteps echoed behind Gu Jun.
A tall, imposing figure approached their table.
He stared at them for a moment, then spoke loudly:

“Who here is Gu Jun? Come to the Martial Arts Club right now. Our boss wants to see you.”

He didn’t even get to finish his sentence before he was sent flying backward.

He crashed onto the floor with a heavy thud and let out a gasp of pain.

The strike had been brutal.

The one who moved was Xiao Wei.

He stood up slowly, walked over to the man now groaning on the ground, and delivered another swift, stylish kick.

“Idiot,” Xiao Wei sneered. “With that weak strength, you dare walk up to someone from Dormitory 3? Haven’t you heard? Dormitory 3 is ominous. And you dare ruin our good mood?”

He leaned closer and added, “Go back to wherever you came from and tell your fucking boss, next time, come himself. Hitting a minion like you doesn’t feel satisfying.”

With a dramatic flick of his hair, he turned around and strolled back to his seat.

Almost every girl nearby looked at him with starstruck eyes.

After finishing their meal, the group left the cafeteria and made their way to the grand auditorium.

It was time for the university’s inauguration ceremony.

The event itself was dull. Speeches, introductions, formalities, nothing worth remembering.

The only highlight was the appearance of Bai Yue.

She stood out like a breeze of cool wind in a blazing summer, calm, elegant, refreshing.
Many boys and even girls watched her with admiration in their eyes.

It had only been a day since the incident, so not many people were aware of it yet. But Gu Jun knew, once word spread, the pressure on him would multiply several times over.

The cafeteria incident today… was just the appetizer.

Thinking of all this, Gu Jun made a soft clicking sound with his tongue.

chapters.name: 30. The Silent Crown and the Ice Born Darkness
chapters.content:
After the inauguration ceremony, there was nothing particularly exciting.

There were no classes today, as it was the first day of university.

Truth be told, Gu Jun wanted to visit the Martial Arts Club, but then he remembered, tonight, he had to visit the elder.

So, after some time, Gu Jun returned to his house.

Evening.

A three-car convoy sped through a quiet road.

After a while, it reached a small hill.

People stepped out of the cars.

Li Ming exited first and opened the door of the middle car.

Gu Jun stepped out.

As they arrived at the hilltop, a door appeared out of thin air, formed from the void itself.

Gu Jun and the others walked through it.

The moment they entered, the door vanished behind them.

They now stood at the beginning of a long hallway.

They proceeded forward and soon reached its center.

Only two people were present, the Left Protector and the Right Protector.

Both protectors bowed and spoke in unison,
“Greetings, Your Highness.”

Gu Jun nodded.
“How is everyone doing?”

“Thank you for asking. Everyone is well. The First Elder has entered seclusion. We expect him to break through to the peak of the Innate level very soon.”

“Good. Let’s go see the Tenth Elder.”

The group continued down a series of maze-like hallways.

Eventually, they arrived at a room that resembled a high-end hospital suite.

Gu Jun entered alone.

The others remained standing outside.

Inside the suite, two people were present.
One of them lay unconscious on the bed, the Tenth Elder.

Gu Jun now stood by the bedside, looking at the Tenth Elder, Longyun, with quiet sorrow. It was a significant loss.

He stepped closer and placed his right hand gently on Longyun’s forehead.

After a few moments, he turned his gaze to another person in the room.

This man resembled a kind uncle, not particularly remarkable in appearance. If anything stood out, it was his gentle expression and the numerous scars across his hands, hinting at frequent work with fire.

But to someone knowledgeable, there was something more telling: the distinct scent of medicine that lingered around him.

This was Longfeng, the Fourth Elder, and the head of the Medical and Alchemy Division of the Gu Empire.

Gu Jun asked,
“What’s his condition?”

Longfeng replied solemnly,
“Not good. He’s lost his Innate Core. He will survive, but under normal circumstances, it will take around thirty years to recover his strength. If we can find any rare heavenly or earthly treasures with healing properties, we may be able to shorten that time considerably.”

“For now, use whatever resources we have in our inventory,” Gu Jun ordered.

“Yes, Your Highness,” Longfeng responded respectfully.

Gu Jun stood and began walking away, with the Fourth Elder silently following.

After a while, they arrived at a massive meeting room, roughly five hundred square meters in size. At its center stood a large, egg-shaped table surrounded by numerous chairs.

Several people were already present, standing respectfully beside their seats.

Gu Jun walked over and sat in the central chair, the seat of command.

Today was a significant occasion.

Why?
Because almost all the important officials of the Gu Empire were gathered here.

Once Gu Jun was seated, he gave a slight nod. The others followed his signal and sat down as well.

He took out a cigarette, his imperial cigarette, and lit it.

As always, the moment he took a drag, a subtle shift occurred in him. His demeanor hardened, and a wave of imperial authority radiated outward.

He didn’t speak for a long while.

He smoked in silence.

Then, slowly, Gu Jun raised his gaze.

On Gu Jun’s right sat the Right Protector, and on his left sat the Left Protector.

The Great Elder was seated directly across from him, facing Gu Jun from the opposite side of the table.

Gu Jun spoke slowly,
“Begin the completion of the Heaven-Encompassing Array immediately.”

The Great Elder nodded and replied,
“Acknowledged, Your Highness. We now have everything needed to complete the array.”

“Also…”

The moment Gu Jun uttered the word, a sharp wave of killing intent and dominance surged from him.

Seeing this, everyone present instinctively straightened, their expressions growing solemn.

“In Antarctica,” Gu Jun continued, “destroy the bases of Country M and Country B that attacked us. Also, eliminate the werewolf base.

As for Country M and the werewolves, leave nothing behind. Erase both life and equipment. For Country B, destroy only the equipment.”

The entire room fell silent.

Then, all eyes turned to Gu Jun, their gazes filled with respect.

The Right Protector responded,
“Order received, Your Highness.”

Then the Left Protector stepped forward and handed Gu Jun a document. It wasn’t very thick, only about ten pages.

Gu Jun took the file and began reading.

At first, his expression was indifferent.

But by the time he reached the final page, a faint flicker of emotion crossed his face.

“So, the Ning family is involved…” he muttered.
“Fine. Help him. First, get him out. After that, we’ll decide how to use him.”

“Understood, Your Highness.”

Gu Jun then stood.
“The meeting is over.”

Everyone rose to their feet.

“Farewell, Your Highness.”

Gu Jun turned and began walking away.

Only the Left Protector followed him.

After a brief walk through the vast corridor, Gu Jun stepped into another massive room.

Inside the room stood a massive crate, five meters on each side. It was clearly a magic tool, and one of innate-level quality.

Something was moving inside it.

Gu Jun observed it for a moment, then asked the Left Protector,
“Have you identified it?”

“No, Your Highness,” the Left Protector replied.
“We couldn’t fully identify it. Judging by its appearance, it’s definitely some kind of bird. It was at the late stage of the Innate level when it fought with the Tenth Elder. What’s truly remarkable is that even after such a powerful explosion inside it, it didn’t die.

In fact, it began to heal. Though its strength dropped to the semi-innate level, it’s recovering rapidly. At this rate, it’ll be fully healed soon. Its regenerative speed is astonishing.”

Gu Jun gave a low hum.
“Open it.”

The Left Protector signaled with his hand, and the crate slowly opened.

Gu Jun focused his attention.

It was a bird.

A strikingly beautiful bird.

Now standing nearly two meters tall, with a wingspan of about 2.4 meters, it radiated a quiet strength.

Its feathers were an enchanting ice-blue, and its eyes glowed like polished rubies.

Gu Jun could barely believe this majestic creature was the same ugly, tattered thing he had seen in the footage of its battle with the Tenth Elder and Code B.

As the crate fully opened, the bird rose to its feet. Gu Jun noticed, with some surprise, that there was no hostility in its eyes or behavior.

When the bird opened its eyes, it immediately looked at the Left Protector with clear fear.

It could sense the threat.

The fear was justified. Even at its peak, the creature was like a child before the power of the Left Protector.

Then its gaze shifted to Gu Jun.

It stared at him, silent, steady, for nearly thirty seconds.

At the end of that long gaze, Gu Jun sensed something unusual.

There was a trace of solicitation in its eyes… as if it wanted to communicate.

And then, just as he was about to speak—

A voice echoed softly in Gu Jun’s ears.

It was the voice of Xuanzhi.

“It’s a variant of the Ice Phoenix,” Xuanzhi’s voice continued.
“Its bloodline is noble, and there’s a good chance it could eventually evolve into a true Ice Phoenix. It’s incredibly old.

Once, these creatures were numerous across the Milky Way Galaxy, but after the last Great War, their numbers dwindled dramatically. They’re a peaceful species by nature and rarely interact with other beings or races.

The fact that it was found at the array piece site means someone used it, tainted it with corrupt elements, and forced it into violent behavior. It was a trap.

Its blood possesses powerful healing properties. Until you find a better method, you can use its blood to treat the Tenth Elder.

Also, humans can form contracts with this kind of creature. However, this species is traditionally more compatible with women as contract partners. In any case, we’ll need some special items to complete the contract ritual.”

“Understood,” Gu Jun replied.

He then turned to the Left Protector.
“I’ll be taking it with me.”

“Acknowledged, Your Highness.”

Gu Jun left the room and entered the next chamber.

It was where the array piece had been stored.

He stood still, observing the artifact from a distance, not stepping too close.

Then, just as he was about to ask the Left Protector a question, something unexpected occurred.

From within the array piece, a wisp of black smoke emerged, thin and eerie, like mist in the shape of a serpent.

The moment it appeared, the entire atmosphere shifted.

It was as if hell itself had descended into the room.

A wave of oppressive cold and gloom settled over the area.

Everyone, except Gu Jun, was immediately suppressed by the pressure.

As soon as it emerged, the smoke-like entity darted toward Gu Jun, clearly recognizing its true target.

Its speed was blindingly fast. Even the Left Protector, a peak Innate-level expert, couldn’t track its movement, let alone react.

All of Gu Jun’s hidden guards and companions attempted to intervene, but they were heavily suppressed, paralyzed by the overwhelming presence of the entity. They realized at once that this thing or being existed on a level far beyond their own.

There was now nothing between Gu Jun and the smoke-like thing.

He stared at it with narrowed eyes.

As it plunged toward him and began to enter his body—

A flash of brilliant purple light erupted.

chapters.name: 31. Purple and Red
chapters.content:
The purple light emerged from Gu Jun’s body.

No one saw how it appeared.

For the first time in many years, the Left Protector was genuinely afraid.

Even if he didn’t know exactly what that purple light was, he could feel that it was something utterly unfathomable. Despite being one of the top powerhouses on Earth, he felt completely vulnerable before it. That smoke-like thing had been terrifyingly powerful, but this purple light… it belonged to an entirely different realm. It held the power to suppress the world itself. The Left Protector understood clearly: whatever that thing was, whether a person or a weapon, it hadn’t even revealed itself. That light was merely a glimpse of its power, and even that had surpassed his imagination.

He quickly turned toward Gu Jun and bowed deeply.
“Your Highness, are you alright? I sincerely apologize; my negligence brought danger upon you. Please punish me.”

Gu Jun responded calmly, “Stand up. Don’t worry, I’m fine. And you’re not to blame. That thing’s level far exceeds yours. What you need to do is be more careful. Earth is not a simple place.”

“Yes, Your Highness. I will remember your words.”

At that moment, XuanZhi spoke. “From start to finish, it was a trap.”

Gu Jun nodded slightly. “Hmm.”

Then he turned and exited the room, instructing the Left Protector to stand down. As he walked toward another chamber, the Right Protector joined him midway.

They arrived at a different office chamber, which belonged to the Tenth Elder. Now, it was occupied only by Code Z.

As Gu Jun entered, Code Z, who had been sitting at a desk, immediately stood and gave a deep bow.

Gu Jun asked, “What is the family situation of Code B?”

“Your Highness, he only had a daughter, no other relatives.”

“Very well. Ensure her safety. If possible, bring her to Tianhai.”

Then Gu Jun turned to the Right Protector.
“Add him to the highest level of the Honor List. His bravery and loyalty deserve it.”

“I have received the order, Your Highness.”

“Hmm.”

After finishing everything, Gu Jun left the base.

Now there were four cars in the convoy, one more than before, added to accommodate the Ice Phoenix.

Gu Jun had decided to give the bird to Di Yan.

She hadn’t come with him today.

It was already late at night when Gu Jun arrived at his residence.

Once he got home, he called for Di Yan. She looked at him with surprise. Gu Jun rarely called her personally. So why tonight?

Gu Jun said plainly, “You’ve been with me for a long time. But your strength is far too low.”

As soon as she heard the first part, Di Yan smiled slightly, pleased. But the second part crushed her mood instantly.

She stared at Gu Jun coldly. “So?”

“So,” Gu Jun continued, “I’ve decided to give you a gift. It will greatly enhance your strength.”

Di Yan eyed him suspiciously. “Really?”

“Yes. Don’t you believe me?”

She didn’t respond, still watching him warily.

Gu Jun sighed and looked at her with a slightly exasperated expression.
“Come with me.”

They walked together into the inner section of the house.

There, a large crate stood in the center of the room.

Gu Jun gestured toward it. “Inside this crate is a bird, a variant of the Ice Phoenix.”

Di Yan’s eyes widened. “Oh…”

Di Yan didn’t look very interested at first.

Gu Jun smiled faintly and said, “Right now, it’s at the semi-innate level. But not long ago, it was at the mid to late stage of the innate realm.”

This time, Di Yan was clearly moved. Her eyes widened in surprise.

Innate—that word carried immense weight for Earth’s cultivators. It symbolized power, prestige, and fear. Even a semi-innate creature was incredibly rare. A being at that level could cause massive destruction in Tianhai, and very few could stop it.

She turned toward the crate, now gazing at it with reverence.
Forget about innate; just a semi-innate beast alone was enough to dominate.

Gu Jun looked at her and added, “I have a method to form a contract between you and the phoenix. Once it’s done, you’ll be able to control it. You’ll understand each other instinctively. You can use it in combat, or however else you choose. Pretty cool, right?”

Unlawfully taken from Royal Road, this story should be reported if seen on Amazon.

Di Yan narrowed her eyes. “It’s nearly at the innate level. Are you sure I’ll be able to control it?”

“Don’t worry. Once the contract is complete, it will recognize you.”

“Fine. I’ll reluctantly believe you.”

Gu Jun chuckled. “Come with me.”

They walked deeper into the house and arrived at the largest room, the main hall.

This community was a high-end one, so the construction and layout of the houses were top-tier. The main hall itself was spacious and well-designed.

At the moment, all the furniture had been cleared out.
Li Ming was already inside, carefully drawing an intricate formation on the floor.

The entire room was filled with the soothing aroma of incense.

As Di Yan stepped into the space, she felt a subtle, sacred energy radiating from the formation. It stirred something in her heart, a feeling of awe, as if the room itself had been sanctified.

Gu Jun handed her a scroll containing the mantra required for the ritual.

Meanwhile, Li Ming and Lin Mo left briefly, returning with a vial of the phoenix’s heart blood.

Di Yan sat down in the center of the formation and began to chant the mantra, just as she’d been instructed.

It took nearly three hours to complete the ritual.

Several times during the process, Di Yan had to be revitalized due to her dwindling vitality. Gu Jun didn’t hesitate; he used some of his finest pills to keep her going.

Once the ritual was finally over, Di Yan couldn’t hold on any longer. She fell into a deep sleep.

By then, it was almost morning, and Gu Jun couldn’t sleep; he had promised Uncle Tang that he’d come over for breakfast.

After a short rest, Gu Jun left the house, hailed a taxi, and headed to Uncle Tang’s residence. Di Yan was still asleep, an unusual sight for someone at the peak of the Dark Level. It showed just how much the ritual had drained her.

Everyone at Uncle Tang’s house was already gathered for breakfast.

After the meal, they had a small sit-down together in the living room.

Uncle Tang smiled and asked, “So, how are you doing? How was your first day at university?”

Before Gu Jun could reply, Tang Xia smirked and said, “He’s living a very sweet life, both inside and outside the university.”

Gu Jun glanced at her.

She clearly knew everything that had happened at the nightclub.

After that, Gu Jun stepped out and got into Tang Mei’s car; he would be heading to the university with her.

As soon as he settled into the passenger seat, a divine sense transmission arrived from Li Ming.

“Your Highness, we have an intruder at Miss Bai Yue’s residence. Our team hasn’t identified his purpose yet. He appears to be at mid-stage Dark Level. The bodyguards have been neutralized, and only one person remains in the house. Should we intervene?”

“Who?”

Although he spoke in a low voice, the confined space of the car made it easy for Tang Mei to hear him. She gave him a curious look.

Gu Jun didn’t respond to her. He was thinking.

Last night, Bai Yue had gone completely off the radar; for all the interested factions, she had seemingly vanished. That kind of disappearance could only be caused by someone with immense influence. Now, with their nerves fraying and no clue who had neutralized their surveillance, some of those factions were bound to react with aggression.

Then the reply came from Li Ming.

“Rong Xi.”

Gu Jun was momentarily stunned when he heard the name.
Then, suddenly, he laughed, loud and nonchalant.

Tang Mei jumped slightly at the sound, startled. She looked at him and muttered, “Weirdo.”

“No,” Gu Jun replied to Li Ming, still smiling.

Bai Yue’s Residence.

Rong Xi stood by the window, watching in horror as the bodyguards were killed.

She was trembling.

What should I do?

First, I need to signal the family.

She pressed a small button hidden within her ring, which would send out a distress signal.

Next, I have to call RAB.

RAB was a government organization, similar to the police, but they only handled cases involving cultivators and other special entities.

She quickly dialed their number and gave them the address.

After that, she began to calm down. The suddenness of the attack had caught her off guard, but she wasn’t completely defenseless.

She knew that no matter who the intruder was, it was rare for anyone to have the nerve to kill her or any woman living in this household. If someone dared, they had to be backed by a truly rogue influence, or perhaps chaos had already begun to unfold.

Even though Rong Xi had regained some composure, she had no intention of being caught. The fact that the intruder had already killed the bodyguards meant this was no empty threat.

She ran quickly and hid under the bed in the maid's room.

Then she heard footsteps, rapid and erratic, echoing throughout the house.

It was just one person, but he moved incredibly fast.

The intruder was, in fact, an assassin.

He hailed from Cloud Island, the most notorious rogue force in the world.

No matter how structured or civilized the world may seem, there are always some reckless influences who rise, believing they can do whatever they please. And when they cross the line too far, sooner or later, someone comes along and wipes them out completely.

Cloud Island was one such rogue force. It was incredibly powerful, classified near the order of Thirty-Three, but its time was almost up.

After searching all the bedrooms, the assassin moved toward the maid’s quarters.

He already sensed that someone was hiding there.

He stopped in front of the room where Rong Xi was hiding.

Inside, Rong Xi felt her heart pounding so hard it was as if it might burst out of her chest.

The assassin stepped closer to the bed she was under.

He crouched down and looked under the bed.

What he saw made his blood run cold.

Two eyes stared back at him, glowing red, like molten fire.

Before he could even react, a slender, beautiful finger with a razor-sharp nail pierced straight through his forehead.

And then… everything went black.

chapters.name: 32. Suncore and The Window of Despair
chapters.content:
It happened around fifty years ago.
Several fragments fell from the sky along with a meteor.

They landed in different places, breaking into multiple pieces.

A few years later, governments around the world realized that these fragments were not ordinary meteorites; they gave off strange readings.

This discovery triggered a global race to collect as many of these fragments as possible.

Naturally, the three major countries acquired the largest share.

Scientific analysis began soon after.

Some nations used the material for healthcare, others for the energy sector, but most directed it toward military applications.

Country M and Country B used it to power their advanced machinery, and in some cases, to create devastating weapons.

Country X also applied it in these sectors, but their primary focus was on experimenting with humans.

After years of intense research and billions of yuan in funding, they discovered how to use this material, named Suncore worldwide, to enhance human cultivation.

It is said that with Suncore, one could potentially reach the innate level of cultivation.

But if it were that easy, it would be too good to be true.

To use Suncore for cultivation, one must endure immense suffering.

In addition, you must have perfect health, suitable physical attributes, and the proper equipment.

Even with all these conditions met, success is not guaranteed.

Reaching the dark level might be possible, but the innate level? Almost impossible.

Even under the best circumstances, perhaps one in a thousand will succeed. Failure, on the other hand, almost always means death.

And that’s after removing as much toxicity as possible. If the toxins are not properly eliminated, the chances of success drop to nearly zero.

In the whole of Country X, very few people have succeeded in doing this. The exact number is unknown, but it likely does not exceed ten, and most of them are from the government, which has the best technology and resources for removing the toxicity.

Three days ago – Arctic.

After most of the ice in the region melted, new possibilities opened for humanity and for the nations of the world. A new sea route opened, a new landmass emerged from beneath the melted ice, and most importantly, a vast deposit of rare earth materials was discovered.

And, as always, humans did what they do best: they began dividing the territory among themselves.

Once again, most of the land went to the three most powerful countries.

And with power came military presence.
This is now one of the most heavily fortified areas in the world.

On an ice cap in the Arctic stood a man.
His name was Yang Leng.

He was unknown to ordinary people; after all, he was no celebrity, but within certain circles, his name carried heavy weight. In the global military community, Yang Leng was a legend.

In fact, he might be the most famous innate warrior ever created using Suncore.

Now, he served as the commander of Silver Spear, the most elite and deadly special forces unit in Country X’s military.

He and his team were in the Arctic on a mission.

The operation was nearly complete. A few minor tasks remained, but they could be handled by others; Yang Leng’s part was done.

Just as he prepared to head back to base, a phone call came.

After hearing what was said on the phone, Yang Leng’s fury erupted, and the icecap under his feet was destroyed.
At that moment, everything changed.

Two days ago.

Yang Leng stood by the window of a small apartment in the capital.

Beside him stood a girl.

He looked at the window and said quietly,

“So… this is the window she jumped from.”

“Yes.”

The girl Yang Leng was speaking to was named Qiao Fenger.
She was the younger sister of one of his closest friends.

When Yang Leng had first joined the army, that friend had enlisted alongside him. They had been life-and-death companions, and he had proven his loyalty through his actions.

Back when they were ordinary foot soldiers, during one mission, that friend had taken a bullet for Yang Leng. He didn’t die instantly; he survived for a year, but in the end, he succumbed to the health complications caused by that wound.

Before his death, he had made Yang Leng promise to take care of his only sister.

And now… this.

“Tell me everything again,” Yang Leng said.

“We saw this talent-hunting ad in an online newspaper,” she began. “They were looking for actresses. We were in the final year at our art college, so we decided to give it a try. It was a mistake; we didn’t investigate properly. The company was new, owned by some wealthy playboy from the capital.

“When we went there, I was disqualified, but Fenger was selected. She was so happy that night.

“Two days later, she came running home, and there was blood on her dress. I learned that a friend of the company president wanted her to be his mistress. She refused. After that, they forcibly drugged her with something addictive, planning to keep her under their control.

“She acted along at first, and when she got the chance, she stabbed him in the genitals. During the chaos, she escaped and came home. She wanted to call you but didn’t get the chance.

“Later, several police cars followed her, along with the company’s private guards. When they tried to catch her, she jumped.”

“Hmm.”

The sound that escaped Yang Leng’s lips was so cold that Qiao Fenger nearly fainted. Sweat broke out across her skin.

Just then, a phone rang.

Yang Leng answered.

There was silence for a few seconds on the other end. Then a voice spoke:

“Yang Leng, why are you in the country? I know there may be some issues here, but you can’t just leave your post. Your mission still isn’t complete.”

At first, Yang Leng said nothing. Then he suddenly laughed.

That laugh was so cold that everyone within a one-square-kilometer radius felt a chill crawl down their spine. In the capital, where many warriors resided, the effect was even stronger. They all turned their eyes toward the apartment where Yang Leng stood. Their gazes were filled with both fear and reverence.

Some powerful warrior murmured “Innate”

“I worked as a simple soldier. Then you convinced me, no, you even morally blackmailed me, into taking the Suncore. Fine. It was your duty. I won’t blame you for that.

“After hellish suffering, I somehow survived and became an innate warrior. Since then, I’ve been serving this country without hesitation.

“And this is how I’m repaid? My sister, who was also the sister of my best friend, the same friend who gave his life for this country, was forced to jump. My sister… the sister of two soldiers… the sister of an innate warrior… was forced to jump.

“And you didn’t help her. Worse, you’re now playing mind games with me.

“And the man responsible is enjoying seven-star treatment in a hospital.

“You ask me why I left my post? So you’re saying I should keep fighting… so animals like that can live happy, promiscuous lives?”

There was a long sigh from the other end of the line. Then came the reply:

“Alright… forgive me for this. But the situation was complicated. The man your sister stabbed was from the Ning family and held a prominent identity.

“You should know the Ning family. They might not be that impressive on their own, but they’re connected to two of the Thirty-Three Great Influences, the Zi family and the Han family.”

“What prominent identity? He’s just a spoiled dandy.”

“He’s indeed a dandy, but his mother is from the Han family; she’s the youngest daughter of the current Han family head. She has a special place in his heart. Because of that, we had to be careful. But ultimately… we did manage to save her.”

“Save her? She’s in a coma, and there’s almost no chance she’ll wake up. She’s just a normal person, not a cultivator.”

Yang Leng took a deep breath.
“Alright. I know why you're calling. You don’t have to worry about it. I’ll take care of it.”

“How are you going to take care of it?”

“You don’t need to know.”

“What do you mean, I don’t need to know? You’re my soldier, our soldier, the face of Country X’s military and the pride of our nation. You should know we have to be careful. This involves the Ning family, the Han family… and even the Zi family.”

“Huh, the Han family may be a problem, but don’t tell me about the Zi family. I know very well they don’t have a good relationship with the Ning family.”

“That may be true, but even for the sake of the family’s reputation, they might be forced to take action. Overall, you should avoid being impulsive. You don’t know much about the strength of the Han and Ning families. We can take revenge, but we must be careful. Listen to me… hello? Hello?”

In the capital military region, also known as the Nator Military Region, inside one of the central rooms, an old man threw his phone away in a fit of rage.

“Damn it, too arrogant!”

Suddenly, another older man entered the chamber.
He then sat on a chair and asked, “What did he say?”

“Boss, this boy is too arrogant. He’ll surely create trouble. The situation in the capital will collapse.”

“Isn't it normal?”

chapters.name: 33. The Capital Trembles
chapters.content:
These two old men were anything but ordinary. They were not mere soldiers; they were pillars of Country X’s military.

The man who spoke with Yang Leng was the deputy commander of the Nator Military Region. The second, who followed him in, was the commander himself, the supreme authority in this powerful region.

The deputy commander leaned slightly toward his superior, his voice low and grim.
“Boss, what do you think? Could it really come to an innate-level clash in the capital? If it does… what’s our move? The procedures are clear enough, but this time, one of the fighters is one of our own. Do we follow protocol, or do we protect him?”

The commander’s eyes narrowed. He tapped a finger lightly against the armrest, a habit of his when deep in thought.
“Hmph. Naturally, we safeguard our asset. But you and I both know this situation isn’t simple. Too many factions have dipped their hands in already. Unexpected turns are inevitable. Still… as things stand, the majority of influential forces are leaning toward supporting Yang Leng. As for an innate-level battle—” He gave a faint smile. “That is not something you should be overly concerned about. You know why.”

“I understand, Boss,” the deputy commander said with a nod. Then, after a pause, his eyes flickered with unease. “But what I can’t figure out is… if the innates really cross swords, how much will the Azure Tower intervene?”

Nator Military Hospital.
A VIP ward, dimly lit.

Yang Leng sat at the bedside, staring at the fragile figure lying under a web of medical instruments.

Qiao Feng’er.

His hand trembled as he clenched it into a fist. He reached out, placing his palm gently against her forehead, searching for some sign of warmth, of life, of hope. But there was nothing. Just silence.

Slowly, he pulled his hand back, his eyes burning with a storm of emotions.

The doctors had spoken plainly: there was little hope.

Sorry, little sister… But don’t worry. I’ll take care of those bastards. I’ll make them bleed for what they did. I’ll carry your hatred on my back until the debt is paid in full.

The Ning family and the Han family had already realized the storm they had invited upon themselves. The girl that their spoiled heirs had dared to harm was no ordinary victim; she was the sister of an innate cultivator. Not just any innate, but a war hero, draped in the prestige of the military.

And the military was not a force that could be offended lightly. It was a vast and perilous behemoth.

The moment Yang Leng returned to the capital, countless eyes turned toward him.

The capital itself seemed to hold its breath, waiting for the storm that was about to break.

In the depths of the city, hidden beneath an unmarked building, there was an underground chamber.

Seven figures sat inside, their gazes fixed on glowing screens and spiritual monitoring arrays. These were the shadows tasked with watching every movement of Yang Leng.

And then…

Boom!

The world above seemed to shatter. A deafening explosion ripped through the chamber, swallowing it whole in an instant. Walls caved, flames roared, and dust surged upward like a dragon of smoke. The seven observers never had the chance to scream.

But the interesting part was not their deaths.

Lurking in the darkness nearby were others, agents from other factions, secretly monitoring those who had been monitoring Yang Leng. When the explosion tore through the underground room, they quietly withdrew. Some wore expressions of delight, some shock, and others cold indifference.

Within ten minutes of the blast, the Han and Ning families received the news. The Ning household in particular descended into chaos. Their pampered heir, Ning Fang, was lying injured in a hospital bed, and now the very enemy they dreaded was on the move. They scrambled to respond, but it was already too late.

Nator United Hospital.
One of the most prestigious institutions in the capital. Its halls combined cutting-edge modern medicine with the ancient arts of renowned medical sects. Officially, it was a hospital. In truth, it was also a fortress, and it belonged to the Ning family.

Yang Leng stood outside its towering entrance.

His steps were unhurried, almost casual, as he pushed open the glass doors.

The moment he crossed the threshold—

WEE-OO! WEE-OO!

The alarms blared, echoing through every corridor. His photo, flagged in the database, had triggered the hospital’s security system.

In an instant, the entire building came alive. Hallways filled with shouting, staircases thundered with footsteps. Warriors appeared one after another, some of the Bright Realm, others of the Dark Realm, and even several of the demi-Huajin Realm.

Yang Leng’s gaze swept over them once.

That was all it took.

Their bodies stiffened, their movements locked as though chains of invisible iron bound them. They were Bright and Dark Realm cultivators, so before his overwhelming aura, they were no more than ants.

Yang Leng walked past them without pause, his expression indifferent.

And then… the horror began.

One by one, the warriors dissolved. Their bodies shimmered faintly before unraveling into wisps of smoke, evaporating as though they had never existed.

By the time Yang Leng’s footsteps faded into the next corridor, the hall was empty.

From beginning to end, he had never even looked them in the eye.

Yang Leng stepped onto the stairway.

Warriors rushed at him in wave after wave. Their blades glinted, their spiritual auras surged, their footsteps thundered.

The result never changed.

Death.

They fell like wheat before the scythe, collapsing one after another.

At some point, his indifference shifted into boredom. Do they not understand? Before an innate cultivator, their resistance was meaningless. Yet still they came, tide after tide, moths drawn to the flame.

By his count, nearly a hundred warriors had already fallen, two of them even Huajin experts.

And still, they came.

Finally, Yang Leng reached the corridor that led to the VIP cabin where Ning Fang lay.

Two Huajin warriors stood guard at the door. Unlike the rest, Yang Leng recognized them immediately; they were from the Han family.

His gaze sharpened. He spoke in a calm voice, but his tone was as heavy as steel.
“I have no wish for enmity with the Han family. You both should know that what lies in that cabin is worthless. Not worth opposing me. Let me kill him, and this ends here.”

The two Huajin remained silent. Their eyes flickered, their grips tightened on their weapons, but they did not move aside.

Yang Leng understood the situation. His divine sense surged outward, descending upon them like a mountain. Crushing pressure bent the walls and warped the air.

But unlike the lesser warriors before them, they did not crumble immediately. Mid-stage Huajin, armed with powerful defensive tools, so they held on, though their eyes betrayed the horror that clawed at their hearts.

Yang Leng did not waste words.

He raised his index finger.

Two streaks of white light shot forth, faster than thought. They pierced directly through the warriors’ foreheads. Then blood trickled down from the tiny, perfect wounds on their brows. Their bodies slumped lifelessly to the ground.

Swift, clean, and absolute.

Yang Leng flicked his hand, and the corpses dissolved into nothingness, erased from the world. Huajin bodies were treasures of immense value, but tonight, such things meant nothing to him.

Without another glance, he pushed open the door and stepped into the cabin.

One minute later, the suite door opened again.

Three figures entered.

The air itself seemed to tighten.

At the front stood an early-stage innate expert. This man was one of the ancestors of the Ning family.

Behind him were two more. Both at the peak of the Huajin Realm. One was Ning Fang’s paternal grandfather. The other, an elder of the Han family.

When the three figures entered the suite, the first thing they saw was Ning Feng lying on the bed. At first glance, he seemed to be sleeping peacefully.

But their divine senses told a different story.

He was dead.

Not the clean death of a warrior, but something far worse.

Every bone in his body was shattered. His organs had been crushed, his flesh torn apart from the inside out. The remains before them were not of a man who had merely died; they were the remnants of someone who had suffered a death soaked in agony.

The three men stared down at the body, rage burning in their eyes.

This was not simply the death of a pampered heir. This was a blatant insult, a slap across the face of two great families.

Especially for the Han family, one of the Order of Thirty-Three, it was more than an insult. It was provocation, a direct challenge to their authority.

There could be no forgiveness. Only vengeance. Brutal, unrelenting vengeance, so that no one else would ever dare the same.

Some time later.

A military plane touched down on the private runway of the capital’s armed forces.

From its cabin descended a tall and beautiful woman. Luo Yan.

Her long strides carried a mixture of grace and urgency. She was a member of the elite military circle, her family long established and powerful within its ranks. More than that, she was known to many as Yang Leng’s potential lover. For years, she had pursued him, hoping to win a place in his heart. She had not yet succeeded, but now she believed she was close.

Now, however, all such thoughts were drowned beneath a tide of unease.

The entire elite circle already knew: Yang Leng had killed Ning Feng.

And Luo Yan understood better than most what that meant. Her family’s heritage gave her insight into the ruthless laws of power. She knew how the great families operated, how they washed away insult with blood. The Nings and Hans would not let this go.

Worry gnawed at her chest.

Instead of returning home, she slid into a black car bearing military plates. The vehicle carried her away from the airport, past the bustling streets, toward Uptown. Her destination was not a residence, but a place whispered about in hushed tones.

The Holy Lotus Club.

A fortress of influence, hidden behind the mask of luxury. Established nearly fifteen years ago, it was less a club and more a sanctum of power. Few dared oppose it, not only because of the mystery and fear that shrouded it, but because its moves were always precise, never reckless.

By the time Luo Yan’s car stopped before its gates, an hour had passed.

The building loomed like a modern castle, its marble walls glowing under the soft shimmer of countless lights, Elegant and Quiet.

Luo Yan barely spared it a glance. She hurried inside.

The ground floor was alive with music and laughter. Men and women lounged with drinks in hand, their laughter sharp, their eyes sharper. Luo Yan instantly recognized faces from the upper echelons, members of the Dongfeng clan, the Zi family, and other powerful influences.

Among them sat the youngest daughter of the Dongfeng family; her presence was radiant beneath the lights.

Her eyes tracked Luo Yan, who was moving swiftly toward the upper floors.

Without hesitation, the Dongfeng girl reached for her phone. Her expression shifted as she lifted it to her ear.

She was calling her elder sister.

chapters.content:
Among the three great orders of the thirty-three families of Country X, each had carved out its own domain of power. The Zi family stood at the forefront of politics and the military. The Han family was famed for its cultivation might, feared and respected across the land. And then there was the Dongfeng family, masters of commerce and pioneers of military technology.

So the Dongfeng is the wealthiest family; only the Eastern Bank and the Medicine God Sect are richer than they are in Country X.

But what truly set them apart was not just their riches or their reach. It was their ability to raise successors. They had long understood a simple truth: the future of a clan rested not on past glory but on the heirs who carried its torch. A prosperous future demanded capable hands. Thus, they devoted great care to grooming their next generation. Each lineage had produced its share of useless dandies, but alongside them always emerged figures of brilliance.

And in this era, brilliance often came dressed in silk and ambition. It was the age of remarkable women, daughters who burned with a sharper fire than many sons.

Among them, Dongfeng Bingling shone the brightest. She was already being hailed as one of the two top flowers of the capital, due to her beauty and capability. Though her family’s strength lay in business and technology, her heart had always leaned toward politics. Upon graduating from Capital University, she entered the Central Political School, where she achieved record results. Now, she served as the secretary to the mayor of Nator, an enviable position for someone so young.

Nator Mayor’s Office

Dongfeng Bingling sat at her desk, arranging documents for an upcoming meeting. The phone on her table buzzed, interrupting her concentration. She glanced at the caller ID and picked it up.

Her sister’s voice came through, hushed but urgent.
“Sister, I just saw Luo Han head into the office floor of the Holy Lotus Club. It must be connected to Captain Yang Leng’s matter.”

Bingling leaned back in her chair, thoughtful. “Hmm… if Luo Han has gone there, then perhaps the club, or the power behind it, plans to move in this situation.”

“Yes. And if they do, we might finally glimpse the true strength behind the Holy Lotus Club.”

A faint smile curved Bingling’s lips, though her tone remained measured. “Don’t get your hopes up. The club has always been cautious. They won’t act just for the sake of friendship.”

“…Understood, sister.”

The call ended, but Bingling’s eyes lingered on the silent phone, a flicker of calculation passing through them.

On the other hand, Luo Han did not take the lift when she entered the fifth floor of the Holy Lotus Club. Instead, she chose the stairway, ensuring that everyone along the way saw her arrival. It was a calculated move, a clever trick that forced the club into a position where silence would be costly.

Such tactics were not uncommon. Families, factions, even entire nations had used similar methods to achieve their ends. Luo Han wanted the message clear: she had come here to seek aid. Now, if the club ignored her, there were only two possible reasons.

The first, that they simply refused. But all the capital elites knew she was a close friend of the club’s manager. For the manager to abandon her now would make the club appear heartless, its reputation stained.

The second, that the club was incapable of helping. That possibility was far more dangerous. The Holy Lotus Club thrived on its aura of mystery and power. If the veil of strength were torn away, their influence would crumble.

After a while, Luo Han sat across from the massive office desk. On the other side, in the seat of authority, was a woman of about thirty-five, elegant, striking, and commanding. She was the club's manager.

The woman studied Luo Han, lips curling into a faint smile. “Girl, you grow more cunning with each visit.”

A flush of embarrassment colored Luo Han’s face. None of her little maneuvers could escape this woman’s eyes. After all, the manager had spent years weaving through the capital’s elites.

“I’m sorry, Sister,” Luo Han said softly. “I truly don’t know what else to do.”

The manager leaned back, her expression gentling. “Hmm. You are still just a young girl. I can’t blame you. And… the situation truly is dire.”

Luo Han’s heart sank. Panic flickered in her eyes. “Sister, even you are saying that?”

“It isn’t the worst yet,” the woman replied calmly. “Listen carefully. I have already reported everything to my master. But my master cannot act on her own will. Approval must come from the top level. That hasn’t happened yet. Still… your lover is an innate. That alone makes him precious, something every great power covets. I believe the top level will lend a hand. But I cannot say for certain. If they refuse, then I can only rely on my own strength and the club’s. Yet against more than one innate, that may not be enough.”
