Her gaze drifted for a moment, her voice dropping almost unconsciously. “In the end, your best hope lies in that person’s decision. If he agrees… everything will be resolved.”

Luo Han blinked, confusion written across her face. “That person?”

The manager’s eyes sharpened instantly, like a blade drawn from its sheath. She snapped back to the present, her stare cutting into Luo Han’s hesitation. “Forget what I just said. It’s better for you that way.”

“…Alright, Sister.” Luo Han lowered her head.

The manager’s voice softened again. “Don’t torment yourself with worry. I’m still waiting for the reply from the top brass. The situation is not beyond recovery. Remember, there are countless powers in the capital, each with its own schemes. Until the very end, no one can predict the outcome.”

The manager paused for a moment, then added quietly, “And there is also… the Azure Tower.”

At those words, Luo Han’s eyes brightened faintly, a spark of hope flickering across her face.

The Azure Tower.

The most mysterious and powerful artifact in all of Country X, perhaps even on the entire earth. People called it a mysterious-grade tool, not an innate tool, because no one truly knew its origin or rank. Its existence defied the limits of human knowledge. What was certain, however, was that it stood above anything an innate warrior could wield.

Unlike innate tools, the Azure Tower possessed a will of its own, a tool spirit. It could act independently, and that alone set it apart from anything mortals could comprehend.

And its function?
It governed the innates themselves.

Every innate warrior in Country X, and beyond, was subject to its unseen oversight. Upon breaking through to the innate realm, a warrior was automatically registered by the tower, their life force branded into its system. From that moment on, they were bound by codes of conduct. Any who dared defy them would face the tower’s judgment, swift and merciless.

It was because of this unseen law that peak innates, upon reaching the summit of their cultivation, were compelled to leave the mortal world behind. The tower tolerated no imbalance that threatened the fragile equilibrium of the mundane realm.

Yet, the Azure Tower was not a tyrant. It carried no personal stake, no bias. Its judgments were considered the purest form of justice in existence. In times of conflict, if innates clashed and the destruction threatened civilian lives, the tower would intervene. Sometimes it would even open an independent space, a sealed battlefield where warriors could unleash their might without endangering the world outside.

To cultivators of Country X, the Azure Tower was more than a tool. It was the silent guardian of the entire cultivation order. None dared defy its authority.

But its power did not rest solely on automatic enforcement. There was also a way to petition the tower, though it was far from simple. The process operated like a vast, impartial council. Seven votes were held by the highest-ranking government officials of Country X, seven more by the seven thirty-three great influences of Country X, and every peak innate held a single vote of their own. Only with sixty percent approval could a petition be brought before the tower’s spirit for judgment.

This system ensured that no single force, no matter how mighty, could bend the tower’s will.

And it was because of the Azure Tower that the Holy Lotus Club could exist at all.

A mysterious influence of unknown origin, the club should have been torn apart long ago by the combined weight of the capital’s great factions. But none dared to make the move. To provoke a force as enigmatic as the Holy Lotus Club without absolute certainty risked destabilizing the entire chessboard. Under the watchful presence of the tower, no one would take that gamble.

Of course, the Azure Tower was not the sole reason for the club’s survival. Careful maneuvering of relationships with other factions, deep financial resources, shrewd use of the laws of Country X, and a formidable reservoir of muscle ensured its continued rise.

So, in the grand game of the capital, the Azure Tower remained one of the greatest anchors of balance, an invisible hand pressing down on all sides of the board.

As Luo Han and the manager spoke in hushed tones, a sharp chime shattered the air. Both their phones vibrated on the desk at the same time, the identical alert tone echoing like a warning bell.

Their eyes met, a silent understanding passing between them. Slowly, they reached for their devices.

The manager’s expression hardened as she scanned the message, her face taking on a rare, dignified gravity. Luo Han’s hands trembled slightly, her features tightening with worry.

The message was brief, but its weight was crushing.
It was a joint statement from the Ning family and the Han family.

For a long moment, silence reigned inside the office. The only sound was the faint hum of the air conditioner, cold against the sudden heaviness in the room.

Finally, it was Luo Han who broke the stillness, her voice strained.
“Sister… say something.”

The manager exhaled slowly, her eyes narrowing as she summarized the words with deliberate calm.
“The statement declares that Yang Leng has committed a heinous crime, slaughtering many warriors, even direct descendants of their families. They claim they cannot tolerate such madness, and they vow to retaliate.”

Her tone grew sharper, each word carrying the weight of the threat.
“They’ve also warned all other powers to stay away from this matter. No government, no military, no outside influence is to interfere. Their intent is clear: they will strike soon, and when they do, they will take their bloody revenge.”
